headline: You will never advance
pros: Possibility of working from home. Only positive
cons: The group is built solely for the white majority. You will never progress as a BAME member of staff. They will make sure of it. In 2020 they did a review after the Floyd incident and the comments that came out were awful. Especially from staff in India whi basically said they were talked down to and berated in a way they never would with onshore staff. I’ve witnessed this myself. The most recent restructure saw a disproportionate impact to BAME staff and you are barely a number to them let alone a person. As soon as I can I hope to leave.

headline: RBS Mumbai Review
pros: Workforce is young and energetic. After one year there is nothing to learn.
cons: Pay is not fair, employees doing the same work have pay variance of more than 5-6lakhs. Work is very operational and repetitive. Mumbai office is controlled by Delhi/Gurgao major proportion of the increments and bonuses are allocated to Delhi/Gurgao with very less allocation to Mumbai. You have to work on weekends as well, work life balance is only a myth. Increments are only 6-8% (as management takes majority share).

headline: Mixed messaging and unclear sense of direction
pros:
- Good flexibility 
- Pay is decent for the role.
cons:
- They say certain aspects of the job are not targets, however, they continue to treat them like they are. 
- Some days can be extremely busy and frustrating. 
- Constantly understaffed. 
- Mixed messaging and no clear sense of direction. One moment the business wants you to be building customer relationships, then they want you to take no longer than 5mins on a call. Certain calls with complex queries can be time consuming, particularly with all DueD checks we must complete, yet with a more varied job role through taking on additional responsibilities these calls naturally take longer. This makes you feel like you're failing at your role even when you're doing the right thing for the business and your customers. Extremely frustrating aspect of the job.

headline: Good workplace if you glass half full kind of person
pros:
Lot of benefits that could be beneficial to some such as bike to work scheme

Lots of Overtime available to give you ability to bump up salary
cons:
Customers service ethos and framework of scrutinising calls and conversations doesn't take into regard the detriment customer's can cause staff's mental health

Management in service do not know what they are doing half the time, it seems to be that such roles are provided due to favouritism rather than merit or their ability to manage people and provide assistance when needed. I have personally moved away from speaking to management for assistance and instead ask other senior members of staff

Bank makes it seem that the ability of promotion is available to anyone and that internal promotions methods are set up in a way to help staff progress within the bank with ease but in actuality that is not the case, staff targets needed to reach before being promoted or even getting a small pay rise are sometimes unattainable and these targets are set higher and higher year by year.

Being a bank that is fully aware of inflation rates and rising living costs the pay provided or the increases in pay rise does not properly address or take in regard these rises

The pay is terrible and does not match the work

headline: Working in Sustainability for banks
pros: As an ever expanding topic thats gaining momentum, working as part of the Climate Centre of Excellence never has a dull moment. NatWest Group were in a position to lead the industry in how to address the climate crisis. The sincerity with which they approached the issue was so genuine and the passion the people in the department have is unmatched. It was a non-hierarchical environment that encourages growth of the individual and the bank as a whole. I had a fantastic time working there, and wish anyone who joins them luck in their career.
cons: As part of a small team dealing with a new and specialist topic there wasn’t always a clear line as to what responsibilities sat with us. I attribute this to the nascent stage of climate within finance, but a con if any would be assignments that will come at short notice.

headline: Slow Growth rate in promotions and in salary
pros:
1 :- One of the best things about this firm is the flexibility and the leaves for Employees. you will get a whole lot bunch of leaves throughout the year.
2 :- Workload is less as compared to other firms , the atmosphere is very flexible.
3 :- Working Environment is ok .
4 :- flexibility in taking Sick leaves : management is cool about the sick leaves , but if it is of long duration , make sure to have a proof for the same.
5:- Management is supportive towards employees
cons:
1 :- Growth is very slow , if you want to grow in this organisation then working the whole day wont work , you need to carry an attitude of being a complete flatterer , or boot licker.
2 :- There are no bonuses for any type of hard work you do throughout the year.
3 :- you wont be getting the appraisals until and unless you wont work very hard for the same , and if you get the amount is not justifiable as per the work.
4 :- organisation is buffed up with corporate politics , if you are going to this organisation make sure to be ready for it. Because the vintage staff wont let you grow even if you work hard
5 :- Managers need to be more educated rather than being the only one holding the title of Manager , they do not work like Managers as most of them do not even know how to work on excel sheets. and if they do then they do not have a proper communication Skills.

headline: Stress Inducing
pros: Good name for your cv
cons:
- Lack of budget means you essentially end up doing three/four people’s worth of jobs 
- They’ll say it’s not target driven but then constantly question why you aren’t meeting targets, and even once you hit 100% productivity, rather than congratulate you and increase other people’s productivity, they’ll set your target to 130% and leave everyone else alone because you can compensate 
- Badly managed - strategy changes every other week and you’re expected to keep up 
- Reluctant to actually help you progress, they demand you should stay in the poor roles for set amounts of time before you could possibly progress, even though this is not company policy and also doesn’t apply to everyone, just poor performing teams with high turnovers

headline: Weak
pros: - Some people within the company are better at feigning an interest in 'developing' the grad population than others
cons:
- Graduate placement managers use graduates as a tick box exercise - route to a quick promotion (or last resort for those who are weak performers and have been missed off for a promotion several times)
- Work you will receive as a grad is so varied, some managers seem to actually value graduates and offer them L&D opportunities and some treat you as an admin assistant/general inconvenience 
- Early Careers are genuinely so weak. Never seen a scheme within Banking/Finance so poorly run and plenty of my friends are also on grad schemes 
- Management talk constantly about D&I but I've personally experienced sexism within my team, witnessed racism and other generally vile behaviours from various colleagues (it's worse the more Corporate you go) 
-The PQ is not recognised, also is very poorly delivered & there seems to be no communication between Early Careers/Placement Managers who in my experience are reluctant to even allow you time to complete 'outside-of-desk' work
-Work/life balance is very dependent on the team you are in; salary is acceptable for what it is - very average grad scheme with average opportunities. If you're a talented grad don't waste your time here

headline: honest review From experienced person
pros:
1) Work life balance is there. you can opt for flexible working hours also. 
2) Employee centric company as in they don't strictly follow hierarchy if you want to raise your concern you can skip the level... and raise your concern even if it is related to your manager.
3) Great opportunity for freshers. Also who are not frequent changer can stay here and settle down.
cons:
1) slow growth or one can say zero growth. 

2) Great opportunity for freshers only, not for those who have spend 1-2 years in this organization. As you will be dragged to internal politics and if you didn't lick your manager's boot you can never find growth here. 

3) After entering into this organization you can't expect people on above hierarchy to be supportive all the time or even knowledgeable. I personally noticed people can't even speak English but are holding some really important positions which can affect other's career.

headline: Absolute mess
pros: Pay is okay, but could be much better given the volume and complexity of work, and brutally high standards
cons:
Shockingly bad IT (full of bugs, lag, system outages) that is not fit for purpose. 

Massive workload due to senior management incompetence so lots of unrealistic targets.

Inconsistent approach to operating procedure because of ambiguous guidance and training which leads to pieces of working taking either 30 minutes or 6 hours, and then staff get interrogated and blamed for not reaching daily targets due to this. 

Lots of team reshuffles due to the massive workload meaning you don’t get a chance to make friends with anyone before they (or you) get moved into a different team. 

No recognition, and no pay increase if reshuffled into a more complex work team. 

Lots of U-turns from management on policies, processes, etc. so always take what managers say with a pinch of salt.

No clear routes for progression unless you're already in a senior position.

headline: Good Company to join as a fresher..but not so good if you are deciding to stay for a long time ..
pros: Office atmosphere is good ..you will meet some good and knowledgeable people who will be there to support you, mostly your team members
cons:
Where do I start..
Work Life balance is a joke
Managers will say they care about work life balance but will also give you a lot of work so that you will not be able to finish on time and if u extend your shift they will ask for the reason so that they don't have to pay for the overtime

This company is so focused on cost cutting that they are literally no ready to pay for the hard work you are doing by extending your shift to complete the work, even if you tell them they will give some excuse and try to not give you overtime pay

People who are looking to work in a company that values it's employee hard work and gives them growth based on their work ..my advice to you is kindly stay away ..here only favorism works.

Every decision taken is based on cost cutting ..even if it makes the employees life hell. They don't care they just want to save money .

Slow growth..and less pay compared to other companies.  For a year of hard work you will get peanuts

No technological advancements..They software and tools they use looks like are meant to make the employees work even harder

headline: Racial harassment
pros:
Salary is not bad.
You can be in a nice place of work  if you not suffer racist attacks from the management
cons:
After long training  they decided if you're able to do your job depending if you're from the country that they want.
They are more focus in your accent than in how you do your job,  if you don't look exactly how the management want  you will have the feeling all the time that they will fired you and if you are not so lucky this is exactly what will happen. They don't mind at all give fake reasons to fired you without explanations.
Also if you have some sickness this is not a place for you as they will look so bad to you and let you feel like a piece of excrement if you need to go 2 minutes to inject insuline or something like that .
Racist and behaviours as daily Basic.
Also you'll be discriminated if you have a disease

- Focus on leading with purpose and supporting communities. This seems to be led from the top and there is a good culture shift since I joined

- Good opportunities for progression for proactive members of staff
- Good training opportunities
- Every manager I've dealt with is well trained and supportive
cons: - Some information/processes can be siloed within teams which leads to lack of awareness/collaboration at times. It can also lead to multiple people doing very similar activities and a disconnect between these.

headline: It was the worst decision of my life to jump from Anz to RBS. I would recommend experienced staff to never join
pros: There is absolutely no pro in working here.
cons: The management does not value the employees at all in Lending operations. Employee satisfaction is a word unknown to them. If your a experienced candidate from another bank in bangalore DO NOT COME HERE. They have no proper canteen facilities, poorest form of transportation, the worst training experience and the SOP and technology is age old and inspite of this they expect wonders from the staff and when that is not delivered they condemn the staff. The staff are always overloaded with work, the SMEs in the process are good for nothing just allocate work and do not provide on floor support. Management inspite of knowing this takes no action and blames the staff in turn.

headline: Best company I have worked so far
pros:
This is my 6th Job and my first review on glassdoor because I have never been in such an employee-friendly organization before. 

Work-Life Balance - Most of the teams here don't expect us to work after 6pm or on weekends. The UK teams are well aware of this fact and they don't schedule meetings after 6pm.

Technology - For a bank, they definitely keep up with the trending technologies. They keep investing in using AI solutions from the market and coming up with their own ideas to improve customer experience

Leaves - There are ample leaves available and the most important thing is, every manager is aware of the fact that we are entitled to take our leaves and they even insist us to take leaves and get refreshed. The bank gave special leaves if the employee or the family members are affected by Covid.

Increment and Bonus - They are better compared to service companies
cons: Not much that I have seen so far

headline: Excellent work culture but absurd upward mobility
pros: Genuinely great leadership, customer focus in its products and services, and a extraordinarily comfortable environment for its permanent employees w.r.t flexible timelines and work life balance. If you're raising a family, this is where you'd want to work. I absolutely identify with values of this organization and would proudly defend it in informal social circles (and this is absolutely rare!)
cons: The company abandoned it's Grow Your Career (GYC or automatic promotions based on time spent in a role) policy few years back and current upward mobility is only possible through Internal Job Postings (IJP) which fails to incentivize good work put in your own project throughout the year and makes career growth entirely dependent on interviews for IJPs given mostly in other teams/areas. The IJP opportunities are far and in between and not proportional to your efforts and simply not enough to sustain staff with growth mindsets/growth needs basis where they are in their career spans.

headline: Not perfect, but improving
pros:
Most colleagues are open to suggestions and challenges
 
Ample support is available to help you meet business goals

Great chances to gain professional qualifications
cons:
Business areas are incredibly disjointed from each other 

The organization is so large that if you stumble across a piece of work that would require assistance from experts in another area, it is exceedingly difficult to find people/teams not already in your network

Slow-paced, going from idea to implementation is unnecessarily cumbersome

headline: Terrible management, bullies, non-inclusive
pros: In a tough climate it's a job I guess
cons: Management need training, they make false promises, they don't care about their staff, they bullied me into resigning and completely took advantage of my disability. Management are often AWOL and have no interest in helping their staff. When you raise problems they promise support, don't give it to you, then use it against you. The worst  workplace experience I have had or ever heard of. Don't work here, it's not worth your mental health.

headline: About the organisation
pros: Work flexibility and work load
cons: Somewhat pay can be a considerable factor

headline: Good work life balance and job stability but less growth
pros:
- You are expected to work from 9-5 mostly and there will never be people calling you at late hours.

- Work from home facility during usual times and permanently during pandemic

-Estimates are provided by developers mostly and not enforced so deadlines are set by developers themselves

- At least in my team, management seems to be very cooperative and friendly and have never experienced any senior being rude.

- Focus on employee wellbeing with 30 annual leaves, sick leaves, option of unpaid leave,
cons:
- Pay for software engineers is not as high as that offered by startups like Flipkart or big tech companies like Amazon, Google, etc. but again isn't too low like TCS, HCL, Infosys, Wipro, etc. Rest depends on your hard work and relationship with manager and the annual rating they give you that how much of an increment you get.

- You'll be working with Java in most teams. Technologies used are- SpringBoot, ReactJS, Camunda BPM, IBM BPM etc, PCF private cloud, etc. Few teams also work Python and AWS data pipelines and the chatbot teams work with Node.js and IBM Cloud. There are also teams working with PL/SQL, Oracle, test automation in Selenium, Mainframe, etc. so basically depending on the team and the role you join for you may like the techstack or end up with very old techstack.

headline: Poor company with historical ideals
pros: Fast paced, opportunity to learn a lot about the company overall.
cons: Salaries are only good when you get to a high level in the bank; starting salaries are horrendous and you are over worked for what you get paid. The ideologies of the business are so dated and there is such a rigid hierarchical structure with an obscene amount of red tape which hinders innovation. I have witnessed countless amounts of nepotism in the business throughout contact centres and also in Services. The 'reward' for being with the company for 10 years? A £10 gift voucher. The bonus system works by rating, like many companies do. However the average amount people got was 1%, which at the time was below the inflation amount in the UK.

headline: Avoid!! clueless and bullying culture
pros:
Birmingham branch
*next to a weatherspoons! And some ok pricey bars.
* pay is alright.
*Do many managers you'll be lucky if you end up with your interviewer or one of the couple if nice ones.
*Unlimited machine coffee
* Vending machines accept card.
* Amazon locker was on site.
* Can opt to put your pay into buying private health care (you have a buffer amount addition to standard pay).
cons:
* Bullying! Everywhere if you say summat you make life worse for yourself so you're trapped.
* Most of the managers are nice to start with but are vile once you're in the job.
* Training is a joke your trained one thing and then when you get on the floor your training isn't used it has no relevance to the job.
* You're always made to feel worthless and replaceable.
* Some staff especially the training provider has so many tall stories you can tell right of the bat who's gullable and who's full of it.
* Monitor everything
* 15 min total toilet break
* Hot desking
* Failure of own values
* Redundant and archaic systems 
* You have to do so much in 30 secs of a call it can be frustrating to the customer.
* So many so called "buddies" give wrong advice and are paired with you after you complete training room days. These buddies are just normal workers that have "been selected as the best in there teams" to show you how it's done. They all have their own ways but if you're unlucky you have some that have no got a clue and clearly blag their way though things and have opted to buddy to get out of doing any work.

Holiday parties are depressing they have no budget and we have to organise it ourself. Everything they do screams cheap and desperate. Have meetings about high staff turnover in the job and how it can be helped yet still treat us like crap and just pretend to care. Only reason I last is due to my direct manager. The actual bank itself is awful not just to work for but as a bank, would strongly advise against banking with them.

headline: Best company to work with
pros: Working with 15 years in RBS was great learning exprience throughout the journey in RBS starting the career in entry level. Best working environment and work life balance the infrastructure of the company is very good. Food , Cab facilities(via routematic) for drop after 9 PM with guards is safe for all the woment employees. RBS Elect tax benefits given are very helpful to resolve the tax issues. Leave policy is very good like 10 days mandy ,Breevement leaves paternity leaves, 5 days of leave encashment.5 days carry forward.Training Academy with the the learning ameditites is awesome. Gym,Doctors for emergency,Library and Club Ace activites keeping us active some way or the other every month, Family day, Long service award facilitations and Town hall with Pankaj in Hilton are always great. Overall its a best place to work like a age old white collar bank jobs with less growth opportunities but will have job security.
cons: Salary Package is very low when compared in the market, Transport to and fro not available at least it can be given for the OIBP Ambathur office as there is not public transport and it lies near the Chennai Bypass. Growth opportunities are very less and too much of politics involved. WFH access not provided for operations which to be considered for the working woment employees which will benefit the health and safety of the women during critical situations in their life. Sick leaves taken for medical emergency are considered as unplanned leaves and impact the rating during the appraisal is the sad part. The IJP and the appraisal process to be more transperant. Rewards and recognisation are to be increased unit wise for the acheivers to encourage every month.

headline: A Good Experience
pros:
There's a lot of Prons but the first and foremost would be, they care about their employees like a family. 
As a female employee, they provide you so much safety and security. 
There's literally lots and lots of benefits but the most important that I think is, the work culture is very good. Yes you are given work but at the same time, your personal development is also important for the bank. 
There's so many programs you can indulge yourself into which gets counted as your work day, no reductions etc. 
They definitely provide a lot of benefits just like other MNCs do but somewhere, this was by far my best place to work.!
cons: There's not much but sometimes the process of hiring can be too long. Also, the policies are very strict when it comes to any rule violation. Even if you're not wrong sometimes you just get stuck in between

cons: Not much! A very good place to work

headline: Employees are always last.Don't listen to staff concerns and ignore when we say something or don't like to be questioned
pros:
Easy job to start with until you are treated like a child

Many employees networks in the business which are good to help the community and colleagues but they lack of understanding from a management level, as some managers don't understand the network importance and think it's a waste of time and don't provide staff time to support the network and expect them to use their holidays allowance  to do that or stay out of hours to do it as they think it's not relevant to their jobs.
cons:
Management dont listen and hate to be questioned. Decisions are made at the top, irrational decisions made without taken customers impact into account.  Staff pay the price when speaking to customers. Staff are never asked their opinions and when we say something we are ignored. 

Terrible HR support, they have no idea of what happen at local level as they are based in Manchester/ Edinburgh and staff feel they have no one they can raise their concern without being judged or worried about being targeted. Many times had to go with the flow as you feel to small to say something in the department or organisation. 

Very hard to move within the business if you don't know someone. You will see yourself applying for jobs internally and expecting to go for a coffee with hiring manager to have a chance of having your cv looked up. If you don't do that, forget about it or you will move nowhere and will stay at the same place forever. If you want to move to another area you need to look outside the bank. You never have the skills or aren't  good enough for the role.

headline: A bunch of low IQ folks together
pros:
Short Term - Decent job for short term : 1-2 years, beyond this you're wasting your time and energy.

Work Life Balance - No work usually (depends on department) after office hours.

Salary - on time.

Stability - For permanent employees, it's a stable company. Although, it's decreasing day-by-day.
If you're on contractual, avoid this and look for permanent position.

Women Friendly - Policies and transportation are women friendly.
cons:
Work Profile - It's a cut copy paste kinda work for all entry level jobs.

Fundamental business is going down while company is profiting from cost cutting initiatives.

Tech : Old, inefficient and faulty program are used by mgmt and the blame is put on analyst for low productivity.

Process Lead/ Process Senior/Manager - 

They'll try to highlight their importance in front of managers/team every chance they get.

Create chaos and behave like school teachers.

Always trying to lick & impress their boss as if they'll get a promotion.

Pray to God, you have a decent manager.

Managers flirt with female colleagues, while a minute number of females (seniors/employees) take this as opportunity.

Some managers will cancel approved leaves and avoid giving holidays to team to impress their boss.

Perception - You should be seen busy or process magical numbers (without quality) will impress managers.

Process Knowledge - Senior analyst share half baked knowledge with new joiners, resulting in quality issues and escalation. Beware!

Restructuring - Every solution to any problem is frequent restructuring. By the time, you learn one process, you'll be shifted to another.

No growth - No matter on which role you join, it's a back office role. It takes around 8-12 years, to become a manager.

Colleagues - Don't be friendly with seniors and managers. Sweet talk but be smart enough. Avoid sharing personal life with colleagues as gossiping is crucial task undertaken seniors and managers. Most people will backbit** behind your back.

Hiring - Too much contractual hiring and delayed joining in last one year. Contractual employees are being extended for 6 months instead of making them permanent.

Cost Cutting - All perks, allowances and leaves are being removed in name of cost cutting.

Sarcastic Trainings - Company will teach you about ethics, anti-money laundering, complaint mgmt, etc. But none of them are slightly concerned about it.

HR - They're here to protect management and their nuisance

headline: Avoid Internal Audit Graduate Programme
pros:
Salary is significantly higher than equivalent roles with accountancy firms
ACA qualification
Impressive offices
cons:
Extreme micromanagement. You will work for audit managers who are trying to get their bonuses (you won't get these), and will treat you poorly via denigrating work and excessive micromanagement leading to loss of motivation.
Nobody takes any interest in your development or cares about your performance. Slow development and work opportunities, so many people fail to achieve the necessary number of professional working days and competencies/ladders to become a chartered accountant. Most people are working in teams where the ACA has no relation to their day to day job for about 3 years.
Salary does not increase, no bonuses, no recognition for good work. Work most days consists simply of admin tasks and compliance with onerous internal auditing methodology so not much room for development.
Incredibly hierarchical structure, work will be reviewed by multiple layers of management, each with their own review points that often will be contradictory in nature and has the effect of being a horrible place to work.
To save money, RBS decided that you have to study the whole ACA qualification online, with no classroom support. The external training provider outside has had significant issues with the delivery of the online training.
Lost of job losses and redundancies as they downsize the department, nobody is safe from this workplace vibe.
Lots of office politics, extreme political correctness and tokenism making it an unpleasant place for a caucasian male. 
Disillusionment means exam failures among current ACA/CA trainees are far higher than the market average.
No decent exit opportunities, either internally or externally unless you are prepared to take a pay cut.
No potential for progression or early promotions, it will take 6 years minimum to be promoted to audit manager despite studying and completing ACA qualification, also the pay becomes less than what job market offers after 3 yrs. No opportunities to rotate internally with different audit teams or to different departments.
High staff turnover so people come and go. Internal Audit is a place full of bank 'lifers' with few skills, and moved around to plug holes in the bank's workforce and where careers go to die.
Very stuffy working environment, few people talk to other teams and sit together in their own teams despite hot-desking. Senior management sitting in their ivory towers have no idea what is going on and rarely even visit the office. Still severe issues with RBS' internal culture, lots of finger-pointing over serious issues and no responsibility taken.
Those with good performance ratings are remunerated by an extra £10/week takehome for years of good work. haha.
The internal job satisfaction survey was very very low for internal auditors who have been there for less than 3 yrs and at 'appointed' (not managerial) level, which is hardly surprising. I would recommend avoiding this graduate scheme if you have a choice.

headline: A changing bank shaking off the past
pros:
As a company, RBS know that with the government as a major shareholder they are going to be in the public eye. So being at the forefront of new technology, initiatives, regulatory change etc is something they have got a lot better at as they see the positive reaction that comes with this.
As a company the core salary is market average, but it's the benefits package that adds value to the appeal of working here.
They do put people at the front of what they do and know that a company the size of RBS and the constant change (including redundancies) they need to focus on their people development and training.
With a new CEO and new vision, purpose and goals soon to be announced, hopefully the bank will spring forward in the right direction.
cons:
The size of the bank means they operate under different brands and different franchises - this can sometimes feel like there is a division with employees i.e. you feel like you are working for different company and not all pulling the same way.
There is still a lot of red tape in processes linked to risk, audit, controls etc and real change does take a long time to deliver.

headline: Honest review
pros:
1)Comfortable place for women
2)Best place for people who are conservative
cons:
1) Organisation framework itself is complicated and age old management
2) No scope for innovation or new ideas
3) For anything (even for internal job posts) you need manager's concurrence
4) Legacy system, no challenging tasks
5) Managers deligate everything, even the personal feedback that was given on the manager
6) Too much of hierarchy, most of slackers are sitting as managers and they have no idea about progress
7) You have to blow your own trumpet, I mean even in appraisal you have to.speak about your positives and manager is so busy in sticking with negatives
8) The bell curve is so big here, so whatever your performance, you will be rewarded "Meeting expectations"
9) Comparisons will be very open, eg., If someone attend office being sick, managers will demand the same from all.
10) Rhetoric and Rhetoric.. for a simple things they speak a lot, action none...
11) Most important point - Attrition is very less, mainly because employees are are not groomed well. Eg., There is separate team to create a simple excel template,  Most of the employees don't bother about this, this is the first and last job for them, they are made to believe that this is a great place to work

Simply if you're looking to acquire new skills or grow, this is not the place!

headline: Adequate but Antiquated
pros:
I have enjoyed my time with the Royal bank of Scotland. Many people aren't equipped to handle the call centre environment and it shows. As much as people like to moan about managers and staff they cannot control how a customer behaves.

Everyone I have interacted with within my centre or within managment have on the whole been lovely. The one caveat to that are the agency workers and certain departments who have a chip on their shoulder. This however does not effect me.

Other Pros:
- Flexibility, I play a sport as a hobby. However my manager and I are able to look at heat maps and re-jig shifts so I cover hot spots to enable me to continue my hobby. 

-Decent holiday alotment and you can buy more through the RBSElect scheme 32days including Bank Holidays and you can purchase and additional 5 days leave.

-Decent culture in the bank and an atmosphere of striving to improve from previous bad press. 

-Senior management are fairly transparent on the whole.
cons:
- My role is taking calls. You will be expected to answer calls. ( Personally not a con but the major complaint from other staff.)

- I handle FPOC complaints and have no change in compensation for this. i.e a new start is on the exact same wage as someone who handles complaints at 6 months. The only difference in my wage is the Annual increase which is tied to Yearly Review by manager.

-Favouritism is alive and well; If your face and attitude fits you will get ahead especially if you get on with your manager. ( I think this is industry wide however it could be a Con)

-You are expected to be Agile. In that Just because your team is booked for a meeting does not mean you will get that time. The issue with this however is early morning teams have a quieter time and will almost never have any off phone activity pulled due to customer demand. However on a core shift you may very well lose your precious time away from customers and never see it returned. 

- Deputies were told 5 weeks before christmas that their role no longer existed and they would have to apply to be TM of new teams or go back to On Call role and accept a wage reduction. The TM roles they have to apply for are open to outside candidates and candidates from other centres. Meaning there is a high chance some will be jobless come January.

-Talent is not necessarily recognized you have to force your way into opportunities. You may suggest 100 changes to process as an agent however all that counts for nothing when you apply for a role in change or journey management.

headline: still a good bank in which to start your career
pros: RBS is adamant that it still has plenty of things going for it. Glen McGowan, head of RBS early careers, tells us that students often join the bank's markets division especially to avail themselves of its excellent training programme. "Our training adopts a blended approach from online modules, external experts, internal experts, peer to peer and senior access because we focus on developing technical expertise as well as soft skill development," McGowan tells us. There are also a lot of 'corporate social responsibility' initiatives at RBS, says McGowan. Students value this, he says.
cons: Ostensibly, RBS's shriveling markets and international banking business doesn't look like a great bet for anyone planning a glittering career in banking. In the past three years, RBS has cut more than 8,000 jobs from its investment bank, pulled out of entire business areas (equities, M&A), and seen its investment banking operating profits decline by 89%. It won't be able to pay bonuses in excess of 100% of salaries from now on. And it's in the process of a serious strategic review which could see its investment bank trimmed back even further.

headline: Worked as a Software Designer in RBS for 5 years.
pros:
Work Life Balance 
Top rating includes better bonus + higher percent hike min 20%.
If you belong to male gender and likes to party, then it is the best company for growth. Here promotions are based on networking , and partying with managers.
cons:
Gender Discrimination : As a female I joined rbs at Associate Level and left rbs after 5 years at same level with no promotions irrespective of the fact good ratings. Was denied promotion due to pregnancy , and post that I decided to quit the organization. 

Inclusive environment missing : Team parties are mostly drink late evening parties which don't consider female comfort.  

This environment drives from top management.

headline: Managers are ruining RBS's reputation in India
pros:
1.   8-5 work
2.   Good Location
cons:
1. Almost all Indian managers treat their employees as their personal slaves.
2. All the reviews you are seeing here is fake.
3. If you are very good at boot licking and don't care about your career growth then this place is heaven for you. If you are skillful and someone who is serious about your career then welcome to this HELL.
4. Organization has given Line Managers the superpower to make anyone's life terrible if they simply don't like that person. Open favoritism and partiality is at it's peak. 
5. Line Managers ask employees to call them "Sir". If you don't follow you are already in their enemies' list.
6. Managers misbehave with female employees and threaten to affect their appraisals if they open their mouths.
7. Unprofessional environment as no one from the higher side comes for auditing and the work environment has become monotony (same as LALA Company).
8. Line Managers are someones from non technical background so hardly they understand anything you work on but always ready to discourage you by setting unrealistic goals for you. They simply don't have any visions. 
9. "God Bless RBS India !!",,,as the iteration rate of talented people is very high and politicians are making this as their second home.

headline: Customer Support Direct Business Banking
pros: Very very nice place to work. Easily accessible via public transport. It’s a great place to work and is very supportive no matter what your situation is. I fell ill on my first week and they said to me to take a few more days off if I still wasn’t well

headline: Good place to start a career
pros:
- Branch team was made up of good people
- Supplied with the IT and training to do my job
- Uniform free and looks fine
- I was only here a short time but it looked like if you start as an APB very quickly you can move into a more senior role in branch and other parts of the business.
cons:
- Not enough staff although they try to get more but leaves people running about like madmen. People coming in and leaving after 4 months like me probably doesn't help this problem
- A small minority of customers are disgusting in the way they speak to branch staff often as a result of having to wait because another customer was there before them
- Customers get angry because the machines 'dont work'. The reason they dont work is that some customers are too stupid to read the instructions on it. These are the same people who remove items from the bagging area in tesco and get angry that the machine keeps screaming at them.
- The investment is clearly in digital which although good for me us a customer to use does make the job look like it will vanish probably sooner rather than later.

headline: Slow Growth, Poor Pay, Bad Reputation in market
pros:
Nothing.

Even work life balance is ensured only in few projects now. But if you are recruited in NatWest Markets, strike this off from your Pros list - there is no work life balance.
cons:
No Employee Centricity.
1. Employees are expected to book their seats every week, even if you are to sit in the same seat.

2. RBS prides itself for seeing its name in employee happiness indexes, which in fact nobody has ever heard of like PCI, Stonewall Workplace etc. You will never find its name in popular great place indexes like Glassdoor and LinkedIn. Because factually, it is a Dead Place to Work in.

3. No Cabs/Free Food provided. There is no pick and drop service for its employees. You can find most of them struggling in metro, buses to reach office, and employees have voiced their concern but RBS is yet to listen.

Bad Reputation in market.
1. If you end up working here, your reputation in the job market drops steadily as RBS carries a very bad name for its UK practices and is shamed for old/stale technological adoption.

2. RBS is now a UK focused bank, hence any chaos in Brexit will deeply affect how it performs - in fact it has decided to cut down bonuses and appraisals of its employees in 2019.

3. Famous for cost cutting measures. RBS has runs cheap employee benefit schemes such as Great Place To Work, Employee Health - which in fact are cheaply funded and hold no actual benefit to employees. You only get to read them in emails.

Poor Pay.
1. Pay is of substandard level compared to its peers and you should expect very slow growth in the company.

Dead Culture
1. You'll find Babu-type desi employees around, who have ended up in the company without true skills and have stayed for over 6-8 yrs in the firm.
2. Ideas are only discussed in meetings, no real implementation is ever seen.
3. You'll be surprised to find - Automation of excel sheets is still the go-to term used in its initiatives, even the top leadership focuses on this!
4. People are slow moving, as its technological adoption is very poor and cheaply sponsored.

Whether its Gurgaon, Bangalore or Chennai, RBS is a dead place to be in and needs to work a lot to improve itself.

headline: One of the best company to work for in Delhi/NCR
pros:
Work life Balance. If you have genuine reason they'll support you in every way.
Less pressure. In RBS even if you are an average performer and you have suitable technical skills you'll face no pressure at all.
Leaves - My favorite part :-) I can bet no company in Delhi/NCR or very few in India have a better Leave policy than RBS.
Medical - Full family floater.
Policies and Culture - Their policies are crystal clear, helpful and employee friendly.
Salary - Their salary is fixed. Nothing variable.
cons: Typical Indian Management  - This is the problem of all companies with Indians in authority. You make them happy, you grow. Doesn't matter how good you are.

headline: Great place to start, just don't stay too long
pros:
Good office Environment.
Close Colleagues 
Some flexibility in the way you work, like working from home occasionally 
Great skills and tools that allow you to eventually move onto a better job.
cons:
Long hours with little leeway for breaks and being late. (If you sign out  1 second early you'll be brought into a meeting.. same with arriving from a break 2 seconds late.) They are just too strict with this and it sucks any enjoyment out of the job.
They prefer contractor staff so they can dismiss you easier depending on workloads. This also gives a feeling that we're separate to the rest of the business and that we're not given the same type of benefits as the rest of the employees. 
Not very understanding managers who will often prey on you, breath down your neck.
Work can get very stale after a while.

headline: Glacial pace - Good to start your career, take a rest or prepare for retirement
pros:
* People are generally nice. There are however several left-overs of people giving attitude here and there. This is a bank after all.
* Some really smart people, but few and far between. 
* Working remotely is encouraged, if not enforced.
* Great for contractors; expect close-to-market rate, relaxed pace of work and glacial pace of change. Nice as a rest between serious gigs
* Great for grads; really easy to get you started. If you are ambitious and able, you will quickly go to a different company to use your full potential. Otherwise, RBS is big, slow and political enough to hide in the crowd and progress with other means.
* Great to retire; loads of people already in RBS are coasting to retirement. You can join them.
* Great for under-represented groups; there is an active drive to hire and promote ethnic groups and women (at least in words)
* Promotion of volunteering, charities, equal opportunities,...
* Great Edinburgh HQ. Good Bristol office. Relatively good India offices
cons:
* London offices used to be human warehouses compared to other tech companies. Situation has improved in some, mice have remained in all.
* RBS is management-heavy even for banking standards.  There are teams with 8-9 non-productive managers for every one contributor. And this is after numerous rounds of lay-offs.
* Staffing is driven by cost, not value. Expect no future in London, as headcount is being constantly reduced, in favour of Scotland and India. 
* Scottish talent pool is a minnow compared to London's. RBS' reputation in India is that of a "safe" place with 2nd rate work; no match for candidates compared to Flipkart, Paytm etc. Result is a constant lowering of the median talent.
* The constant brain drain and hiring freezes has resulted in a vicious circle of hiring only contractors, buying expensive COTS or outsourcing to external suppliers. For its size, innovation and technology in-house is negligible.   
* On the other hand there is incredible waste of money at the technical level. 
Huge projects in the tens of millions delivering little to no value. All. The. Time. Comparing with how efficient challenger banks and trading upstarts are, it is rather depressing. 
* Expect to make no difference as an engineer. Not because it is a big organisation, but because few to no technical decisions are based on technical merit. Politics and hippos rule (highest paid person's opinion).
* Pace of change is glacial. Everything and anything takes months or years. There is incredible bureaucracy for every single thing. There is a deep hatred towards automation. RBS lags behind technically at an ever faster pace, burning even more cash trying to catch-up.

headline: Easy to see why it needed bailing out.
pros:
- Decent work-life balance. 

- Ability to work from home regularly. 

- Relatively low pressure compared to other banks.

- If you want to hide for a career, this may be the place for you (especially if you're not in London).
cons:
- Relatively low salaries and practically non-existent bonuses.

- Lack of ambition

- Edinburgh is MASSIVELY over staffed while London is far too lean in many teams. Understandable to an extent as London is expensive, but to witness the comparably low level of ability out of Edinburgh staff, it makes you wonder if hiring a few decent staff in London over 3x as many in Edinburgh makes more sense?

- Distrust of the more mature investment banking arm by, basically, everyone else in the bank.

- Many staff that have been around far too long - most still exhibiting the behaviours that got the bank into hot water to begin with.

headline: Fair employer however employee benefits degraded in last 10 years.
pros:
Medical cover/car allowance 
Life cover 

Great focus on personal development in particular - professional qualifications relevant to your career 

Good holiday entitlement - which grows with service/seniority.

Business definitely has an entrepreneurial spirit, offering individuals the opportunity to be creative and individually responsible for improving things. However there is often still a lot of red tape in particular from middle management/senior leaders.

Executive are very open to new ideas and creative ways of doing things. They have a real commercial and supportive manner for the most.
cons:
Less ability to cross pollinate roles for such a large organisation (as it’s getting smaller) and most certainly more silo’d - like it was many years ago.  It’s challenging for people to work in other functions of the business from which they started 

Banking benefits very poor (all readjusted and many removed after the bank crisis) 

Massive focus on positive discrimination of women. Eg. They want more women in senior positions. Whilst this is great - the organisation is falling into the trap of meeting a target instead of getting their basics right and employing the right person for the right job.  

Challenges in recent years have meant lots of instability and varying degrees of competence in senior leaders. A greater focus on basics and stability required.

headline: Relationship Manager
pros: The company invests a lot in its employees in terms of training, professional qualification. There is also an increasing focus on work life balance as the company tries to move away from historic image to match the current shift in banking culture.
cons: Still very bureaucratic in terms of processes. Could do a lot more to improve internal efficiencies as there are many internal processes that are a waste of time.

headline: On-boarding/KYC Officer in Guildford
pros:
Obtaining KYC/AML experience in a large financial institution.
Access to various SMEs in this space.
cons:
Long commute from London plus the train ticket price per month=approx. £415. 
Very rarely obtaining a day to work from home.
Very very long hours and a lot of pressure from the managers to complete your cases. 
2 huddles every day (morning and in the afternoon).
Only some colleagues had access to other system in order to perform some further checks on the companies we were on boarding. Given this, we were dependent on them to complete some of our cases which contributed to the long times customers had to wait for their account to be open.
Very low salary.

headline: Best Place To Work If You are a Native

cons:
If you are anywhere other than Tamil Nadu, Always be in touch with your load balancing team, It's extremely helpful to not to lose your mind.

Don't discuss your Professional/ personal life or secrets with anyone for any reason - it will backfire.

Don't lend money to local people from your team.

headline: Technical Product Manager

- Good work life balance if you push for 8-5 things.
cons:
- No concrete efforts are seen to implement visions of CTO level management on grounds. Looks like government policies which are implemented on paper with hardly any changes on ground
- Extremely difficult to make your voice heard if you don't know people
- Lots of cost cutting happening from free food,  to cabs,  hardware infrastructure
- Hiring standards have been degraded in last 2-3 years
- Slow career growth

headline: Corrupt
pros: Gave me a good foundation to move onto better companies
cons: In the Manchester offices, the management set up was not based on talent or capability, rather who had been romantically involved with who. This lead to corrupt teams, uncomfortable working environments and unprofessionalism. When reported to Senior management, a blind eye was turned. The senior management do very little, other than pass jobs onto staff members. No accountability from leaders who expected accountability from you. Broken promises. 'Appraisal Structure' again was solely based on favouritism rather than actual performance evidence. Like wise with the bonus structure.

headline: Good job for someone who wants to work in finance.
pros:
Some of the things you learn are worthwhile and things that you may use again. 

The people you work with they make the job so much more enjoyable.

Everyday is different so it will never be the same which makes it interesting.

Good annual salaries and benefits.

Good hours and hardly any weekend work.
cons:
No proper training for the specific job role I was doing.

The customers are a lot more difficult to deal with than retail or customer service in general. 

Expected to take on a lot more than your job role feel you’re running round doing everything yourself. 

Management are sometimes lazy and have attitudes toward some of there staff. 

Some days are very overwhelming and stressful with the things that need to be completed during a working day.

headline: Team Leader - Birmingham Contact Centre
pros:
- Room for progression within the department if you show the right behaviours and dedication.
- Salary increase when you have your annual review in Dec (salary increase will be in April following year).
- Multicultural and open to all religions and cultures.
- They tend to support progression within the company.
- HR services are very good within the company. 
- Decent pay for the job that you do.
cons:
- Hours are sometimes not very family friendly.
- Competitive environment (staff can be untrustworthy and disloyal to each other).
- At entry level they sometimes hire the wrong people (they need better recruitment processes for entry level jobs).

headline: Horrible Pay Master and NO Growth Organization for technical professionals

Lowest salary in the industry.
Zero technical growth. Zero professional growth.
Only focus on growth of managerial staff which is also btw quite dissatisfied.
Single digit hikes and increments, good hikes are reserved for only very few key folks in org, no value for new entrants. No way to build the new entrant’s capability.
Old and disgruntled tech and managerial staff in both UK and India.
Very very dominant leadership.
No open culture, you are not asked for opinions, even if asked rarely, it’s just for record purpose. No relevance or action.
UK and India management behave like government employees- no professionalism; managers are like those filthy government babus who treat their staff like peons.

headline: Crooked Practices & A Terrible Workplace
pros: Literally no Pros to this organisation whatsoever
cons:
Encouraged to "upsell" to telephone customers asking for account balances, despite being employed to provide them with details of their account.
After being asked to review the company honestly, a manager was assigned to groups of people to "monitor" the responses which employees were providing to a questionnaire provided by head office.  Actively encouraged to change responses which were deemed unsuitable.  This practise is illegal.
Offered "kickers" for upselling people to different accounts and encouraging them to take out various indemnities, insurance and accounts.
When groups of employees were given the news that they would be losing their jobs, team leaders created groups in the call centre names "huddles" then looked at each other in unison, before delivering the news together.  A ridiculous approach, rather like a cull, very unethical, and crass.
The manageress encouraged us to give her a good review, as a bad review "could affect her pay".  I personally would rather have left an honest review, not a skewed one. 
I could go on and on.  It is a terrible place to work, and certainly not somewhere to carve out an eventual career.  There is no room for manoeuvre if you're an ambitious individual, the workplace itself has a very sorry feel.  Simply avoid at all costs.

headline: A very mixed bag
pros: Reasonable pay rates, generous holiday (25 days plus Bank Holidays plus option to purchase and extra 5 days), some flexibility in working hours (as long as you can do the same - which is fair enough). If you can stomach the culture you can learn a lot - though it's as much about how not to do thing as it is how to do them properly.
cons: I worked at the Thanet Grange call centre and the watch word was 'expediency'. Today's absolutely mission critical, 'everyone's running around like headless chickens trying to achieve it' priority will be forgotten by the tommorow  - even though the problem still exists. Some very weak managers who are led by personal bias/favouritism and impressed by gobbledygook management speak rather than self evident (if inconvenient) facts, leading to some incredibly knuckle headed and short sighted decisions  - be prepared to face palm multiple times daily. Too much emphasis on achieving certain meaningless statistical targets at the expense of overall performance in areas that really do affect the bottom line. No senior managers around after 6pm  - not good when the call centre opens and deals with high call volumes until 9pm. Not a place to work if you really care about getting it right  - has had deleterious health effects on me and others I know. Beware managers who are happy to leave their work for you to manage when it suits them, but who don't like it when you dare to express a relevant and useful opinion when it doesn't. Too much credit and attention given to those who neglect their core duties to do tasks that curry favour with managers, too much slack given to people who are well liked but obviously not performing as they should  - need to make sure the rock solid reliable performers -  who actually deliver the real work - get the credit they are due.

headline: The RBS Culture
pros:
- Family-like working culture 
- Thorough training
- Great individuals across the bank
- Despite media claims, RBS genuinely is a bank that is sorry for its past and actively tries to reorganise itself to suit the customer's needs.
cons: A lot of nepotism, I mentioned above the family-like culture present across the bank. This can be somewhat detrimental if you have any desire to “progress” or be “promoted” within the bank. Progression is extremely slow as people tend to have their feet “firmly under the table” where movement is concerned, often meaning that new (senior) roles rarely open up and if they do (see aforementioned point) you do not stand a chance if you’re not in “the circle”.

Only 14 minutes break (used to be higher)

Cliquish environment in centre I was based in, did ok if pals with certain people.

headline: Plenty of cracks behind the glossy cover
pros: Pay and benefits in line with industry average
cons:
Company has some nice to aim for goals for 2020 however at its core it's not changed much it was bailed out.  Tries to do the right thing for it's customers from time to time however constant cycles of the same change and as management changes, they re-invent the same ideas that lead to more pressure on sales staff and not always treating its customers fairly.  Further claims of mis-selling, compensation and redundancies are a matter of time.  

Staff morale very low and many managers just remain in their positions for too long to care about the staff.   Internal employee opinions often conducted under senior management supervision to achieve a glowing score.   

Culture of the organisation doesn't allow for healthy constructive criticism and often a reactive company that will act when comes under scrutiny of regulators.

headline: Disappointing progress
pros: It’s a big organisation with lots of opportunity. Ross McEwan the CEO is incredible and inspiring. He cared about his people and his customers and is genuinely trying to do the best for the bank and for Britain.
cons: It’s big but incredibly slow. The bank is a dinosaur, it’s systems are fragile, red tape everywhere. It’s trying to change but it’s resistant. It can’t make progress quickly. Too much dead wood, too many people trying to do things the old way. It’s slow and disorganised. But, there is huge potential if only people can get their ducks in a row. Ross is an inspiration, but his ExCo having different and competing agendas, which appear disorganised and creates the confusion and lack of speed to turn the business around.

headline: Needs an overhaul
pros: RBS has some very loyal and kind people working, but these people are extremely rare to find nowadays. Most people who are here long term are bitter and resentful.
cons:
Where should I start?

The first is that RBS has many many departments that dont talk to each other. As an example, you are a manager who needs 20 resources. Most of these resources are needed for 1 or 2 days to implement something in production. Now there are disjoint departments (will definitely be 20 departments since you need 20 resources due to the silos in RBS) with their own format of huge word documents, sharepoints and sometimes online systems. For each of these resources you will need to fill in the same information in 20 different formats (some of which take weeks to fill in). You think thats the job done? Absolutely not. Now you will not only need to chase these 20 departments, but they will also randomly allocate resources to you in 2018, 2019 etc even though your project ends in 2017 and you have mentioned that in whatever format of form they asked you to fill up. Then to get these resource dates amended, go back to start of process and fill the same forms again. It is tedious and stupid beyond belief.

If you are not an IT person, this is probably a good place to work. But if you take years for planning any IT project, then by the time you deliver the project your technology will be so severely outdated that only the RBS employees who are also customers will know how to use it. It is compulsory for an employee to open an RBS bank account so 100K of their customers are 'compulsory customers' anyways along with many more who have worked here in the past but are too lazy to change their bank.

Secondly, the number of contractors they have outnumbers the permanent people by a huge margin (was something like 10% permanent). Due to this, the number of people doing short time fixes and patch is higher than people who think long term (long term here is anything greater than 6 months). The contractors don't really care about the bank but just keep patching things over and over instead of planning for fixing them.

Third, the 'blow your own trumpet' culture. Some departments keep doing this over and over. If their projects fail, they get incidents, they still act as if things were a massive success and start rewarding people in bulk. In these pockets, even If someone sneezes, they get an LOV award (living your values). Other departments meanwhile do not even reward their people if they make millions of profit. The reward system is not related to what you achieve, but depends on the type of mental disease your management has in that either they will go overboard thanking people even if they have failed, or they will not thank at all. 

One more thing, their layoff strategy has no basis. Someone critical to a project could be laid off, while someone else with nothing to do will be kept on. Mad really. 

They now have location based layoffs. Most people in London are being laid off now as they have a strategy to have most people based in Scotland.

headline: Shade better than Indian PSU Bank - long way to go!
pros:
1. Good work-life balance

2. Similar to point 1, employees' are taken care of in regards to providing sufficient leaves and work from home options which always helps.

3. Brand value - it does matter!
cons:
1. One of the worst in IT. While many have moved to workflow tools, RBS still works on Excel sheets. Microsoft Office 2007 or 2010, poor lagging systems across the office.

2. They operate like a PSU bank (in reality, they are!. Lack of planning and even poorer execution of it.

3. Every simple thing is made complicated due to inefficiency. (too many instances to list)

4. Although, it's a widely used partially inaccurate statement but it holds very very true for RBS India - HR department is highly unprofessional in working! It has largely been outsourced and hence the unprofessional behavior exists.

5. One of the worst cafeterias I've seen. They don't bother too much as there are limited options outside the office. Expensive and poor taste/quality.

headline: RBS serves over 19 million customers predominantly based in the UK and Republic of Ireland. We have three customer fran
pros:
Serve customers well. This is our purpose.

Serving customers
We exist to serve customers. We earn their trust by focusing on their needs and delivering excellent service.  

Working together
We care for each other and work best as one team. We bring the best of ourselves to work and support one another to realise our potential. 

Doing the right thing
We do the right thing. We take risk seriously and manage it prudently. We prize fairness and diversity and exercise judgement with thought and integrity. 

Thinking long term
We know we succeed only when our customers and communities succeed. We do business in an open, direct and sustainable way.
cons:
No much opportunities to work in variety of technologies and tools. 
Not adequate cab facility
Less number of datawarehousing projects.

headline: Loved my 5 years.... but left because I didn't buy into the future vision.
pros:
Large company so tonnes of room for progression internally. 
Lovely people - I still count many of them in my closest friends 3 years after leaving. 
High capacity for new ideas and approaches as it knows it has to reinvent itself. 
Embracing of diversity.
cons:
I found it hard to believe the brand would be able to turn itself around. I felt that unless they shrunk MORE drastically, or even split into a retail bank and an investment bank, then they wouldn't be able to rebuild the brand and give people faith in the organisation. 
They have a lot of 'lifers' - who've been at the bank for 30 or 40 years, and haven't worked anywhere else. That breeds a friendly family feel, but not a dynamic future looking organisation.

The bank is still working through legacy conduct issues, these seem never-ending and lead to negative stories in the press, which can undermine staff morale.

headline: RBS
pros:
Top up benefits added onto the basic salary make the pay rate decent.  
Can gain external qualifications and subscribe to take courses on their intranet page but this is kept rather hush hush.
cons: Plenty of politics within RBS but then again which large organisation doesn't have that. The thing that makes RBS the worst is its recruitment model. Lower down you have fantastic talented workers who everyone always goes to when they have a problem or need help but these people don't get promoted. Its very much who you know in RBS, not what you know. You wont get anywhere here without brown nosing upper management. The culture promotes it. Team leaders don't really coach development either in staff, as long you are hitting targets and making their life easier then that's all that matters to them.  Plenty of managers who a. couldn't run a bath and b. are in it for themselves.

headline: Overworked and underpaid
pros: It's allowed me to gain valuable experience and paid for qualifications
cons: No one is willing to admit when things are not working as everyone is keen to please the person next in command. I.e. hours, removal of bonus, weekend work

headline: Technology - Infrastructure Engineering (London)
pros:
- Great people
- Flexible working (can work from home almost full time)
- Lot’s of interesting work that needs to be done, if you’re interested and ambitious you can shine
- Decent benefits package
- Good senior management comms
cons:
- Lowest pay in the financial sector
- London slowly closing down as it’s “not strategic”
- Impossible to gain promotion if in London due to above
- Impossible to move sideways if in London due to above
- Moving out of central London for those that remain
- Change control process is beyond belief - it’s a true barrier to getting anything done
- Anyone really talented tends to leave quickly just because they can
- Lots of deadwood just waiting for the golden redundancy ticket or hanging on for the final salary pension. 
- Massive amount of siloing, very difficult to get collaborative efforts going

headline: Actions speak louder than words

- legal matters

- childcare 
- caring for the elderly etc
cons:
Bullying, favouritism and too much change

Too wooly

headline: After nearly a decade it was the right time to go.
pros:
Initially started out as a Temp handling savings and loans queries for 6 months before moving on to telephony based Debt collecting role 

Provided very good training, always facilitied by very experienced members of staff. 

Being a massive organisation gives you plenty of routes for a solid career path where I ended up within Corporate Banking.

Courses such as the Certificate in Lending (via the Chartered Bankers Association) was compulsory but also paid for by the firm which I found incredibly useful.
cons:
Being a large organisation also allowed slackers to exist alongside those who really gave it everything therefore was frustrating how these individuals were never disciplined or picked up enough on it.

Towards the end you were pretty much lied to about job security and never felt as if your job was safe, a more honest approach would have been appreciated.

Offshoring a lot of work to India, hence my redundancy, however this will have a negative impact on service given the distance between clients and portfolio management teams, especially at Corporate level.

headline: Sinking Ship that will continue to sink - Racist and bullying management - Avoid

They will also make you look bad when they feel you are a threat to them. During my time I was bullied on countless occasions, I was victimised and my development was supressed hence my departure after 10 years.

headline: Lots of lovely people but a tough gig
pros: I worked there for over 11 years in total.  There were lots of lovely people and I was given many opportunities including working overseas and working in different departments.  These experiences have formed a large part of my career and have given lots of learning and development.
cons: RBS whilst it remains part Government owned will always be a punch bag for the press in the UK.  That's not easy and the drive to run a lean operation sometimes means you're running to stand still.  I left September 2014 so things might have changed but in the end I wasn't sad to leave.

headline: Mixed bag
pros:
Pockets of great intent, energy and talent
Fixed comp is fair (if not consistently so)
Relatively humane work-life balance
Huge amount to do so, for the tenacious, there is a lot to learn
cons:
Stench of failure will persist until we turn a profit (which should be soon according to analyst guidance)
Questionable career path if you are London based
No credible defence against the coming Kodak moment
Regressive management practices persist despite genuine widespread efforts to upskill management (e.g. forced rankings on a bell curve for all permanent staff)
IT is an expensive, unreformed hair ball holding the firm back
Over-reliance on off-shoring as a cost saving strategy 
Internal divisions are relatively rife (investment banking vs retail, London vs Edinburgh, Risk vs Finance, CIO vs CTO, Tech vs Change)
Data strategy appears to be dysfunctional
Variable comp is poor, understandably given the comments on profit

headline: Brilliant organisation!

- Too much focus on London and Edinburgh, rest of the locations play second fiddle

headline: Pay peanuts and....
pros: Having worked elsewhere, there is nothing RBS does better
cons: Low level of capability of staff driven largely by monetary rewards lagging other investment and retail banks.  It's a very odd sensation to be in an organisation which is state-run, needs to reduce it's budget (often by 10% a year) and trying to retain talent.  It can't !  Those who are left are split in 95% sheep and 5% wolves.  The wolves are talented and smart, but the environment is geared to eliminating people.  Talented people scramble for the door, so that the sheep become more bedraggled year after year.  Very strange to be working where the only qualification for being there is that you haven't found a job elsewhere or you haven't been downsized.  The only way people can mentally survive is by tricking themselves that everything is ok, even though they sit down and someone else has 'disappeared'.  A happy-clappy moon-cult is left and still the wolves prowl round the ever dwindling bank of sheep - but even the wolves are aware of their own eventual downfall....

headline: Downsizing Bank
pros:
The CEO and Executive team are very engaged in turning the bank around. 
The majority of staff at the bank are wholeheartedly committed to making the bank profitable and acting in the best interests of customers.
One of the best teams I've ever worked in, with everyone genuinely having each others back.
cons:
As the bank down-sizes there are immense pressures on the teams that are there with very little acceptance by senior and executive management of this. 
The bank lacks any real ambition other than the core buzzwords, which can be disheartening at times. 
Concerns raised with senior / executive management either bilaterally or in the annual staff survey are not listened to. 
Limited career opportunities given the need to get smaller and reduce costs.

In head office, like any big organisation, most of the work is routine and "box-ticking". As a result it boredom usually sets in after 3-6 months in a role.

headline: Final years of many at RBS was as a Test Analyst
pros:
The people in my team were great and everyone seemed to get on with each other. I even keep in touch with my old colleagues.
The card centre building is modern and has good facilities (watch for low flying aircraft)
A posh sounding department name of Central Unit New Technology Services.
cons:
The salaries for Test Analysts are an absolute joke. Be prepared to lie about your salary to be taken seriously if you want to leave. When I left my salary increased by 89% to essentially do the same job. 
Don't believe management when they tell you that your earnings are in line with other companies, they are not even close believe me!
Terrible internal interview process means you will only progress if you can talk. You don't need to know what you are doing. This could explain the state the company finds itself in?

headline: Good pay, good work-life balance, no reward structure
pros: In comparison to similar roles, the position was well paid and the hours I had to work per week, along with the shift patterns were pretty good.
cons:
As to be expected, the company is going through a huge period of change and uncertainty, and I felt that staff morale was usually last on their mind once these changes had been implemented. 

My training was all over the place due to poor management of my mentoring scheme, and I was also moved on to another during the first few months of being in the role due to efficiency savings. With all of this in mind, there was no consideration for how this impacted on my personal development, and often felt huge gaps had been left in my training, and also felt a bit left behind and forgotten about, whilst also still having a lot demanded of me.

No personal recognition for good performance in terms of sales or service. 

I also felt there was a lack of company culture. Did not really feel a part of the business, or that I was particularly contributing to anything at all. I just came to work, did the job, and went home again.

pros: None now.  At least not until the restructure is complete.
cons:

headline: Relationship Support Manager
pros:
Exposure to the many processes within commercial banking
Diverse.

Great for those who're simply looking for a paycheck at the end of the month

Simple 9-5 working day. Most employees (including senior)have left the building by 17:05.

Historically a stable role however this is likely to change during 2018 due to planned redundancies by CEO. Ross Mcewan plans to have the bank profit making by 2019
cons:
Low wage bracket when compared to identical roles within HSBC, Barclays & Lloyds bank.

Many outdated processes which need updating.

Reluctance to streamline processes as the bank staggers through its divestment phase.

Not much in the way of progression due to planned redundancies of senior roles.

The bank processes are mostly archaic & tedious. To the point where they need to be taught first then an individual must inevitably rely on trial an error to complete a task.

The bank fails to effectively invest in upskilling the young talent. Mainly caused by its new found focus on risk. This is born from the bank needing to be sold as ordered by EU commission after 2008. 

Unreliable appraisal process 

Employee needs are often overlooked

-Although there is a fair amount of diversity within the bank, there is an obvious "boys club" phenomenon apparent within most teams. This unfortunately leads to those who don't fit the mold being overlooked for progression opportunities. 

Notorious high turnover throughout all teams.

No Bonus - Pay increases are minimal 6% for standard annual appraisal. this then decreases to 4% once within 90% of the maximum salary
