headline: Awful company to work for
pros: Very few pros, salary for the position is okay but not great. Would not recommend any part of RBS - I actually recommend moving banks they are that poorly run
cons:
Where to begin - 
Team managers are lazy and seem to enjoy constantly threatening people's jobs over losses which they admit they would have done the same thing on. Some won't even do their job the first hour of their shift - even when built out to do a specific task they rely on normal members of staff and not even deputy's to run an entire department while they go to the canteen when supposed to be working - I have had to do their jobs whilst also juggling mine many mornings. 

The floor managers (bar 1 however I will not name names) are abysmal. None of them have any people skills in a job where it is essential, and not a single ounce of compassion. An example would be where a colleague was needing surgery and they would not give that person a day off for an essential pre appointment and demanded they swapped a shift. Another would be a refusal of a holiday for a MOS who needed that as she was receiving IVF treatment that day. 

There are literally no routes of progression other than working up to manager level as every department connected to fraud which is non customer facing is facing redundancies and downsizing with their jobs being moved to India, for no reason other than to save RBSG money. This means that the entire department is depressing with it being a matter of time until another persons job is moved over to India. 

The bonus system has been edited to benefit staff less, and the grades for this can be given to you by someone who doesn't know you at all and only goes off of statistics such as AHT which actually makes no sense - by all means not wasting time on calls is important. However the amount of pressure put on staff to reach ever lowering targets meaning that customer service skills are thrown out of the window in order to get a customer off of the phone as fast as possible. 

Absences and the treatment you receive in regards to this seems to be very inconsistent in the way that some staff members jobs are threatened after 2 absences in six months yet that same manager has had more days off due to absences in the last 6 months than they have been in work; leaving work early and making up random reasons why (boilers broken at home... at midnight and so nothing would get done until the next day after their shift would end anyway). 

There is a reason there is, as my manager puts it, a "revolving door" of staff. It's not the job itself; the job can be interesting especially on higher risk calls when unskilled. The reason people are constantly leaving is the ridiculous treatment of staff highlighted above and then the pressure put on them by staff leaving and not replacing them in a timely manner. This means that there are more calls waiting to be handled, creating worse cases to deal with through escalations and complaints. The place is ran with no long term plan in mind and because of this there will never truly be a change. No one wants to work in a place where you feel you're constantly at threat for losing your job for menial reasons.

headline: See me after school
pros:
- Flexibility. RBS is quite good at working around part time staff who have parental responsibilities. The working week is generally 35 hours, which is quite short (although makes it difficult to get things done sometimes)
- Inclusion. RBS is also quite good at ensuring that people from all backgrounds get into roles.
cons:
- Pay - HR as in many large organisations are overworked and understaffed. They're also very crafty and if there is any opportunity to take from your pocket to reduce their costs, they will take it.
- Unprofessionalism - this is inconsistent across the organisation however certainly in my area staff are not treated like competent professionals, and in many cases staff do not act that way either. That's very much "six of one, half a dozen of another".

headline: Bad - Protection Direct

cons: No continuity across different teams/managers (every manager tells you something different). Too much focus on risk and "red calls" - this creates a very negative atmosphere. Low morale throughout office (management have resorted to creating a "fun committee"..). Almost no prospects for promotions & employees not approved to work on internal secondments although the department is over staffed. There is a lot of talk about "doing the right thing for the customer" but it is no doubt a sales environment and staff are heavily pressured to meet arbitrary targets.

headline: Corruption and Favoritism at its Peek
pros: subsidized and mediocre level breakfast and food, subsidized CAB service. and good bonus if you are able to get it. :)
cons:
It worse than a Govt company, People hire their wives,siblings,cousins by misusing their power, its an example of severe corruption .it ruins the team environment when managers always favours his relative or friend and not treat them as a team mate.

Very limited Growth opportunities, you will get promoted if you have some godfather to support you. your sole talent can not give you a WIN in this company.

performance appraisal process is very much hidden and peers are not treated fairly, whatever your LINE manager is saying you have to accept ,you have no choice, because there is no third person or HR person can interfere .

Due to this at the end employee is trapped and become frustrated. and in no time the good talent leaves the organization which are a backbone of  the Bank. Line managers don't even care about their reportees. most of the times the feedback is just adjudicated and derived out of their actual performances. lack of a 360 feedback also makes the process a bit unfair.LMs don't even want the employees to attend the Global leader townhalls so that the voices can not be reached to the people.

and last but not the least HIGHER management is too busy to involve in these issues so they do very less on engaging with employees.

headline: Average company,good to start with,not to retain for a longer time
pros: Good to start with,work environment is not serious,people are friendly & food coupons is a plus point.work atmosphere can suit anyone,no work pressure but there are moments of meeting the deadlines.
cons:
Team leaders harass their team members,can go any length at disturbing them.On a personal front managers lack a professional way of conduct & disregard them.

People term this company as a brand that can lead to better opportunities at a thought of exit but that the very brand name is just for namesake as most people join other companies by employee referral.

This brand has not added to my future growth & no other company has rated me on a positive note of RBS at the selection process.canteen food is not upto the mark & cause health issues.There is not much scope for growth.
Cost cutting is a trend nowadays as a year has passed since the afternoon tea(free) has been stopped.At times managers are too bossy.

headline: great culture for work life balance

cons: Large complex organisation with lots of politics. Due to the bailout, there are constant restructures and cost reduction challenges, which makes it difficult to innovate and make real changes.

headline: it is an awful place to work, sinking ship
pros: Nothing, absolutely horrible place. You'd be mad to work here.
cons: I would not suggest working here. Management are intolerable, you don't know whether the branches are being sold or staying with the bank. So much negative press and customers use that as ammo against you. Goalposts get moved, success is never celebrated, only failure is picked up on.

headline: Horrible working conditions
pros: Most of the other employees are friendly, decent salary. High paid career prospects
cons: Only care about sales and targets. Tried to constructively fire me when I had a long term illness backed by a doctor. Felt bullied by the upper echelon of the company. Lot's of the more wealthy employees took lots of cocaine and cheated on their partners with hookers.

headline: Project Manager
pros: Lots of opportunities to experience different roles within one organisation. Self development well supported.
cons: The approach to flexible working depends on the individual manager that you work for, even though the policies are very and inclusive. Too much change over the past few years has left staff with little idea of what needs to be achieved on a day to day basis. It's alright having a strapline to aspire to but that doesn't help get the job done.

headline: Worst employer I have ever worked for
pros: None really, they pay you on time, but that's it.
cons: Very low salaries for what we are expected to do and no bonuses. Lots of cost cuts and redundancies everywhere. Worst thing is the bank is replacing staff with very inexperienced people and paying them peanuts, teenage apprentices, or moving entire functions to India. It's going down the toilet, not the company it use to be. Morale at the bank is at an all time low with older staff preying for redundancy so they can leave. You might as well call it The Royal Bank of India now.

headline: Sadly Becoming A Toxic Environment For Staff
pros: Very inclusive in terms of LGBTQIA and there are lovely individuals within the Thanet Grange office. Yearly salary reviews based on a combination of your performance and the group's performance.
cons: Increasingly toxic environment. Increasing number of redundancies of experienced staff, followed by realising that they now lack the correct number of staff required to do roles. Many roles outsourced to Shared Services India, where due to a lack of training errors have now increased leading to further costs to the business. Group policy says to do the right thing, but most managers don't listen when you call out issues and you're quietly told to drop points, even when they affect customers.

headline: Good company
pros: I enjoyed working at RBS Markets and International Banking. My colleagues were intelligent, hard working, able and amicable. The IT systems and controls that we had in place were very good and well thought through & implemented. People care was also good, with training and development available to employees. All in all a good company, genuinely sorry to see them still suffering.
cons: None really that I can think of, except for maybe the fact it was a large organisation so you felt a bit anonymous, as you might do in any large organisation.

headline: RBS

headline: RBS
pros: Work ethic, salary, management (local management), bonus and pay structure, work life balance. Only now writing to get to twenty words

cons: Lots of inefficiencies especially at executive level.  Bonus culture drives wrong behaviours, ie very short term view.  Leadership do not lead by example.  Frontline and middle management staffing levels have been cut back too far and to the detriment of customer service.

cons: Little support once part of a team- this does vary by team, but largely not sufficient, appropriate support.

cons: The bank is undergoing significant change to become a UK only bank and this has had a significant affect on head count - Very little opportunity for young individuals to progress their future.

headline: Intern

cons: General depressed feeling due to the cuts to most of the areas of the bank. Values of the company are rammed down your throat to such an extent that they have become a bit of a running joke across the bank.

headline: Wirk
pros: Great work life balance.  Less work. Focus on fun
cons: No delivery focus. Management sucks. Very coterie driven

headline: Technology Graduate
pros: During the graduate programme you complete three eight month rotations to help you build a solid understanding of the business and gain a variety of transferreabke skills. Through each rotation you are given the opportunity to obtain a qualification which is subsidised by the company. By the end of the programme you're CV will be looking well rounded with a mixture of managerial and technical skills.
cons:
Due to HR paying your salary not the team that you are actually working in, many teams apply for graduates due to them being a free resource. 
Many of the teams that you work in are in need of a graduate however some do not. This leaves some graduates with little work to do. Graduates however do give feedback to HR and if they are feeling under-utilised they can move teams.

headline: job satisfaction
pros: good organization to work with
cons: technology and system issues is very bug concern

headline: High Turnover - Constant transition
pros: Good people, relaxed atmosphere, good work hours
cons: High turnover, Office Politics, Lack of Leadership

headline: Hard work, well rewarded
pros: Great people - highly capable teams, clear structures, Very accommodating of alternative/ compressed working hours. Good emphasis on personal development. Gogarburn HQ facilities are excellent. Decent focus on personal wellbeing too.
cons: Basic office tech, though Lync/ Skype for Business voice call capabilities are coming. Will save a lot of time/ money on conference calls. Single monitor set up is standard. Lots of meetings. Immature service/task management systems. Business standard approach to change management - i.e. Changing processes as part of business as usual, making successful change limited.

headline: It's a great place to work , be ready to be flexible
pros: Good work life balance , great people , helps you become more flexible , always learning , gym on site , management works hard and very hands on .
cons: Restructure , too many IT problems , no increases , no bonuses ,  uncertainty , low morale , too small

headline: RBS
pros: There is plenty of opportunity to move around within a large organisation such as RBS.  The people here are all working together to make the bank strong and customer focused again and you really do get a sense of that
cons: Can be siloes with three separate franchise businesses and all of the separate functions serving them.  RBS is obviously going through a long period of change which can result in a feeling of uncertainty amongst employees

headline: Mixed, constant state of turmoil
pros: Some great people, those that have been there man and boy or those that are newer to the business
cons: Restructure after restructure after restructure - seemed like 1 every year, with redundancies, job role changes and those that are left picking up the slack

headline: AML Professional
pros:
Good Place to work and had a every good work life balance .
Had lot of learnings
cons: Less Package and growth opportunity is very less

headline: Good place to kick start career
pros: Great development opportunities. Competitive pay compared to competitors at entry levels. Great pay package options. Always opportunities available within RBS to progress internally. Mentorship programmes etc make the place and senior managers highly accessible for those looking to progress
cons: As the bank looking to be one a lot smaller focusing on the domestic market, opportunities are there but not as readily accessible. There is a lot of competition when looking to progress internally.

headline: Officer and Analyst
pros: Best Managers, Work-life balance, learning curve.
cons: Too much Flexibility in working hours.

headline: Best Company to work for.
pros:
Empower/trust their employees to take key project decisions
Good work life balance
Provide realistic career road-map to employees
cons: None I can think of

headline: Good
pros: Role and work were good
cons: Too Bureaucratic and too much push back from people

headline: The most toxic environment I've ever worked in.
pros: Good learning opportunity - RBS is putting out so many fires at once that there's always a critical project going on.  They say smooth seas never made for good sailors, so imagine how much you could learn by joining this sinking ship.
cons: Lack of opportunities, unbelievably negative culture.  Most of the talented people left RBS over the last 5-10 years, and those that remain are only there to maintain their final salary pensions, so totally unmotivated.  It's a terrible, soul crushing place that has no real redeeming factors.

headline: Getting better in terms of Team environment but...
pros:
Great Team environment. 
Immediate Line Management (in my experience based on last role) genuinely care about the wellbeing of the Staff.  They went out of their way to assist in very difficult personal circumstances which developed in the latter part of my employment.  Whilst this has not always been my experience, I feel that immediate Line Managers are getting better at this due to a lot of investment by the Bank in wellbeing.
Flexible working - also includes working from home on occasion
cons:
Work still being outsourced to Poland and India to cut costs
Organisation moving as much work out of London as they can - either elsewhere in the UK of more likely abroad.
Teams within UK are being disbanded/restructured in line with the above

headline: Great people, poor business direction
pros: Selection of training, People, Responsibility
cons: Lack of direction, changing business priorities

headline: It depends where you land
pros:
Flexible working arrangements (work from home, working hours,...)
Good head quarters

headline: Mixed bag....

cons:
Genuinely believe the top guys believe their desire to be #1 for service trust and advocacy but not sure they really know what it's like to be part of the organisation.

Constant changes of structure lead to very very unsettling times. 

Benefits all but withdrawn. 

If you've been there a while you need too leave to keep up with "real" market pay ranges. (I had a £16k pay rise when left).

headline: The worst environment I have ever seen
cons:
The whole corporate culture. Very few people care about what they do there. Very slow processes, what can be done in 2-3 weeks at another company will take months at RBS. Very low discipline. I was shocked when one of the departments (IT networking and telecom) confirmed 4 meetings in a row and just ignored them, nobody showed up. It is a very "political" environment, some teams pursue their own interests only and sabotage initiatives, back-stabbing happens. As the company is (mis)managed from the UK, you won't be empowered and won't have professional opportunities at the US office.
If you like getting things done, if you expect peers to be responsive and responsible, this is NOT the right environment for you. Beware.

headline: Doing things for sake of doing things
pros: Generally good level of business and management support for Work-life balance with good level of benefits including annual leave, once you've been there a while and reached a certain grade with many internal career progression options.
cons:
Bank is restructuring so always felt uncomfortable that jobs are going, lot of work moving from UK to India which contributes to redundancies. Lots of building closes as bank downsizes after the expansion explosion 10 years ago. No job security and no appreciation of staff.

Performance reviews based against objectives and culture of under performing if don't hit every single one All The Time but if you hit a few over the the standard it doesn't even out. Not allowed to have a voice or challenge things without it being seen as negative. 

Constant doing things for the sake of doing things and for no reason where there are no business benefits which wastes every ones time and effort and takes people away from doing their actual job. 

Salaries low compared with competitors, bank continually messing with the Pension stuff so employees end up getting less and less their pocket.

headline: Ugly ethics and still as bad as ever......
pros: Looking in my office today ? Id say very little pros. The negativity outweighs the good. Ive seen the appraisals, the mess you make of the employees through this, the calibre of the managers that are let loose and what damage they do, the whole system is rotten, it reeks of self promotion and incompetent individuals... but we know no better....
cons: They say a tiger doesn't change its spots, well this is probably a pretty adept to describe this conglomerate as it is still as rotten to the very core as it was before the crash. It knows no shame, and it is still very much about getting profit before anything else. On first impressions it may look slick but reality is that its sick. This is a company that doesn't care about its employees, a company that has no morals. Its a basket case. As long as the upper management get their bonus they have no cares for the business or for the people in it. I listened to a meeting and you know they are so insular and detached, planning on how to cut wages and mess with the junior ranks, they wont go. And they think it hilarious at what they are doing to the pension. Really if you have any sense and moral compass then you would give them a miss. Any opportunity with RBS is a wasted opportunity. Think outside the bank, what are you going to do when you make a move from the bank ? you will have RBS on your resume and you know what the rest of the world thinks of them.

headline: Great people, felt like the civil service
pros: Although a lack of overall culture, the staff are friendly and helpful and the workplace can offer some limited flexibility for work / life balance.
cons:
Disjointed and process led. All the talk is on 'doing the right thing' for the customer, which means very little when  translated into service. The bank works because of the staff that remain there, the systems and just about every process seems to get in the way of the staff in the bank. The bank systems (can't say too much) are ancient, not linked and full of 'sticky plaster' solutions, it amazes me the FCA / PRA allow the bank to operate some of the systems they do. 

In the last year pension benefits have been eroded, bonuses scrapped (only for the lowest rungs of staff!) and there is next to zero investment in training, culture or retaining talent at the bank.

The overall culture at the bank is very much like an arm of the civil service, there is little drive for efficiency, a lot of tribalism and 'computer says no' attitude, and an upper management completely disengaged from the base of the bank. We don't 'sell' we 'help', we don't do mortgages we do 'dreams', pseudo culture brought in from the most cost effective 'corporate advisers'. It feels like switching the band on the titanic, the tempo might improve but the ship still sinks! And we wonder why it's been nearly ten years since the bank turned a profit? (we're told every year it's 'mistakes of the past' i.e 2008 credit crunch, however this is getting quite distant now, and it's hard not to believe these are in fact the mistakes of now).

headline: Analyst
pros: No Pros working for this company
cons:
Progression is only when you know someone or hang out and party with the managers. If you apply for other roles within the Bank you are threatened of being moved to another area far from home or else your manager calls the manager for the role you apply for and tell them you are not releasable.
There is no training in this bank, they rather pay lots more money and bring in external staff than up skill their own staff.
Worse Bank to Work for...right from Retail Banking. TOO MUCH POLITICS

headline: Private Banking Officer
pros: Good location and canteen facilities. Benefit funding is good with a wide range of options available. Opertunities if your face fits!
cons: Little flexibility, mandatory rotational shift patterns making it impossible for anyone with others responsibilities (kids) childcare is not rotational. Good opportunity for promotion if your face fits. Removal of bonus for lowest payed staff ( customer facing) has plummeted moral.

headline: PMO

cons: Lack of structure, not the best atmosphere if you do not sit near team

headline: Plenty of opportunity
pros: Great company to develop in and potentially decide your career path. Progression as fast or steady as you dictate with great training
cons: Competition ...... lots of experience... it sometimes seems that roles have already been earmarked. More focus on external qualifications is needed as experience doesn't cut it in the outside world

headline: Good place to work but shrinking
pros: Good life-work balance, decent hours, generally good environment.
cons: Getting political, business shrinking outside London

headline: Trying to be better, but not fast enough for me
pros: I worked with great people and many were very determined to turn the bank's reputation around. I felt empowered to get things done most of the time and had access to senior leaders who were willing to listen. Great opportunities for creative, adaptable results-orientated people - you can carve out a place for yourself if you can prove you're adding value.
cons: The past just continues to haunt RBS. It can get depressing. There are also many people who just aren't committed to doing what needs to be done to turn things around... they are just assuming they can let others sort it out for them. Would love to have been a part of the transformation, but new opportunities called and I faced the fact that I could be waiting a long time for RBS to be the kind of organisation I could be truly proud of.

headline: Clerk

headline: Fails to reward loyalty, hard work and experience in the long term.
pros: Excellent remuneration package for management, 30 days holiday + Bank holidays, wide range of job opportunities available, good training available, good physical working conditions.
cons: Highly stressful jobs with no appreciation for working excessive (unpaid) hours, year on year low salary increases and exacerbated by removal of previously enjoyed perks of subsidised mortgage/ loans, free car parking and non-contributory pension scheme. Pension scheme now lower pay out, later retirement date and now contributory. Loss of 1,000's of highly experienced and high performing staff over the last few years as Departments have been rationalised and with redundancies based on location as opposed to skills, experience & performance has led to higher work loads for those remaining and less opportunity to provide the level of customer service that staff want to provide. Targets/ performance expectations remain in place which continue to drive wrong behaviour in some areas.

headline: An organisation under pressure

headline: Started off well when I joined back in 2012 - but it ended on a sour note
pros:
- Base salary and benefits package
- Career progression
- Training 
- Ability to work from home
- Ergonomic care
cons:
(All of the cons apply to the past year)
- The company lost its sense of direction 
- Lack of leadership within programmes
- Budgets and approval processes delayed the on-boarding of required resources. This resulted in people working ridiculously long hours which effected the work life balance
- Highly stressful work environment
- On-going internal restructuring resulted in constant uncertainty of position
- They do not pay you for any remaining holiday when you leave (you have to take them or you lose them).

headline: On the up?
pros: Allow you to get on with job with minimum supervision. Clear task identification. Clear and generous benefits package. Minimal intrusion.
cons: Although minimal management remains amateurish unskilled and thoroughly Unprofessional. Wish the exception of the actuarial specialty all other qualifications are regarded with suspicion if not contempt.

headline: Senior Relationship Manager

headline: It's been good
pros: Flexibility and Variety....these have kept me with RBS for almost 30 years where I have acquired so many skills that are truly transferable. Coupled with great people and previously great travel opportunities it has been great but...
cons: Restructures, financial constraints and still trying to pull ourselves from the mire is debilitating and demotivating.  Difficult to see where future opportunities will come from as hierarchy is flattened; my area of expertise has a clear end life within organisation....a case of when, not if.  Reward is a poor joke....most of us are regular bankers who don't see bonuses, shares are almost worthless and pension erosions are hurting those who were sensible back in the day

headline: Senior AML Analyst
pros: work-life balance, atmosphere, not very demanding, available trainings, great people and management team, available language courses, recognition for job well done

headline: Lacks leadership
pros: Working hours, pay and benefits. The review requires a minimum of twenty words however I genuinely cannot think of another positive which after 30 years service is a poor reflection of how bad the company has become.
cons: Terrible management and leadership at all levels. Poor IT systems and processes. Customers deserve a lot better. Centralisation might save money but will reduce service levels.

headline: Used to be great :-(
pros:
- Great people on the whole
 - Opportunities are there if you want them and are willing to make yourself 'visible'
 - Excellent benefits package, flexible/home working in many areas (but not all)
cons:
- Endless change without any real direction, or time to see if the last restructure has actually worked before embarking on the next one.
 - Little consideration for those who just want to do their job well without climbing the greasy management pole.
 - Large scale redundancies purely to reduce headcount resulting on most of the experienced members of staff leaving.  The Bank will be largely staffed by Consultants (at inflated daily rates) before long.
- The shed-load of now worthless shares I invested in.
- The buzzwords and management speak... dear Lord, the buzzwords really get to you after a while

headline: Excellent
pros: Great people and great work experience. It is a fun culture. It is a good place. It is very good. The people are nice.
cons: The bank seems to be downsizing. Moral was starting to hurt.  People are leaving. People were somewhat afraid to lose job.

headline: Not as good as it used to be
pros: Company is generally very supportive of flexible working patterns. Depending on manager, grade etc working from home is sometimes available. Help with career progression & self development. Some decent benifits like being able to buy extra holiday days.
cons: More & more off-shoring of work abroad is having a demoralising effect on existing staff. Job security has definitely decreased sharply in the time I was at the bank. Ok salaries, poor bonuses.

headline: Respects work-life balance but parking is a nightmare
pros: The culture is very supportive of a wide variety of flexible working patterns (part-time, compressed, term time etc) and this is very common. Also more informal arrangements such as working from home are positively encouraged.
cons: Parking at the Edinburgh campus is a constant headache, which will only be made worse by more people being moved into Gogarburn Head Office building.  The previous needs based system has been replaced by a one size fits all, which means those with genuine personal need (e.g. Regular childcare commitments) now don't get a permit and therefore need to allow extra time (30-60mins, as the public bus often doesn't arrive to timetable) at the start and end of the day to go to the Park & Ride which has significant impact with fixed school / nursery drop off and pick up times. This results in more work needing to be done in the evenings to make up for this additional time lost out of the office.

headline: Has changed a lot
pros:
Good Employee Facilities - Cab, Food, Leaves
(Though Cab facility getting closed from November, Food charges being changed from April next year and Compliance Leaves are no longer valid and mandatory)
Adaptable environment - hard for those who want to work hard, easy for those who want to relax
Timings - 8 to 5
cons:
-- Not technical focused organization, Likes to do things as per cost decisions and not what's latest and what's the best. So, if you want to grow in IT space, you should think before Joining
-- Too much internal politics, Jobs cuts from London further creates a bitter n political environment between the global teams
-- The appraisal process is not transparent and there is no proper growth plan, neither the management is interested in discussing the same
--Management is biased towards specific people and doesn't think from perspective of the team
-- Only care about cutting cost at the moment

headline: RBS - Technology Services.
pros:
Remuneration package is quite competitive. (but they are spending tax payers money after all)

Ross McEwan deserves a medal (give him Fred's!) for his efforts. What he has inherited to try to fix is nothing less than abhorant
cons:
1. Massively incompetent senior management team in Tech Services who are entrenched in a pre 2008 leadership style. 100% Self belief 0% self awareness. Most of the long term SMT are just waiting for the cheque. Hierarchical bullies who don't know any better. 

2. The do not know what they are doing. Conflicting priorities. Lack of direction. It is a huge concern that they have a responsibility to look after so many peoples money. 

3. They waste SO much money on aimless projects. The place is crawling with consultants and day rate contractors who are happily taking the cash. The answer to every problem seems to be to throw money at it and then hope for the best

headline: Dysfunctional

cons:
Saddled by government ownership of which it has no chance to repay in full.
Wound down Abn Amro (a poorly run institution) and relieved the Dutch tax payer of the burden in doing so.

headline: In transition
pros: Senior leadership are making a clear and commendable effort to be open and honest about the ways in which structural changes to the business will affect staff on the ground. It seems as though this effort is doing something to mitigate the loss of productivity associated with such a far-reaching restructure.
cons: Middle management culture is very backwards. Associates and VP's have a very old fashioned culture where analysts are not respected and are taken for granted.

headline: Things don't seem to be getting any better
pros:
Good annual leave at 30 days per annum
Supportive line managers if you get the right one (few and far between)
There are a few people who want to do the right thing to push the organisation forward
Customers are the focus of most of the organisations initiatives
The heart of most senior executives are in the right place
There is a focus on trying to support the development of women to senior positions in the organisation, but this is counteracted by a severe lack of internal opportunities.
cons:
Intensely political, this always gets in the way of anything getting done
Senior managers and execs. are generally pale, male and stale
Senior managers are blockers to anything useful happening in the organisation
There is very limited opportunity for growth or promotions
The majority of employees are holding on for retirement or redundancy packages
Majority of employees are self-interested with short-term focus as they don't feel supported to take a bigger view.
The atmosphere can sometimes be toxic (due to senior management self-interest, constant restructurings, cost cutting initiatives that don't move the dial and focus on the wrong things and a general daze).

headline: Good for Freshers
pros: No pressure and good environment to work . They provide best safety precautions.They have best leave policy. Cab facilities are good
cons: Monotonous and you cannot move easily from one process to another .if your manager is not good then you will not be recognised

headline: Pros and Cons of working at RBS
pros: People, work life balance, location (Gogarburn)
cons: Senior Management, processes, legacy systems

headline: good start in work life
pros: loads of small advantages, medical package, parental help, bonus for vacations. And a very nice atmosphere of work
cons: It's a big corpo, so changing things takes a while, and moving up the scale takes some time. Perfect if you are patient and can live with a lot of immovable preset rules, not so much if you have an entrepreunerial spirit.

headline: Good Company BUT
pros:
I have worked with RBS for 2 years.

1) Work Life Balance
2) Good work in some projects
3) Cultural events
4) Very Good Food
5) Enough Leaves
cons:
1) Seniors are just seniors. They just rule. They even don't have much technical knowledge. When they leave at 5, will give you some work before leaving and tell you to complete it today. This was in my case otherwise there are many people enjoying Work Life Balance.

2) Work From Home is limited. Very limited.

3) Pathetic Bonus. 

4) Not too good in terms of increment. Even if you have worked in a very good way, you won't get good increment and bonus.

5) Favouritism is there

6) Policts is there as normal. You will have to go everywhere with your manager, then you are doing something good. Else is below than normal.

7) Tough to get trainings. If you want to get some training depending on your wish, you can't because the training which you want is not relevant to you. Pathetic! Isn't it?

headline: Case Manager, Ombudsman Complaints Team
pros: Depending on which department the atmosphere can be really good. Really nice and helpful colleagues. Supportive line management.
cons: Systems, are really old and need updating. Simple tasks can become really challenging just because of this.

headline: Bad for career growth
pros:
1. work life balance 
2. no work pressure.
3. Lot of leisure time for other activity
cons:

3. Old technologies

headline: Well-rounded graduate programme
pros:
Depending on what division you are in:

- Good investment in interns and graduates
- Help you do courses such as the CFA
- Lots of training when you first join, technical and soft skills
- Launchpad if you want to start a career in Finance

this is most likely not going to be the case in CIB, but more so in CPB division.
cons:
- Rapidly changing company and culture of risk-aversion and compliance heavy (more so given gov't owned)
- Pull back in investments in graduates and junior's in the CIB division
- Constant restructuring meaning job security isn't there
- High employee turnover
- Often high amount of negativity among employees

headline: Great place to work
pros: RBS is a great place to work. As a firm it has a great work life balance. Good opportunity to grow.
cons: No advice to management. Although not many opportunities in India. Due to the discussion to close the retail banking business.

headline: Good work life balance
pros:
Facilities are good.

Flexible working (Work from home)

headline: Work Load and Lack of Strategic Directions
pros: Great people that I worked with...
cons: Lack of Strategic Directions and resources...running in fire fighting mode adhoc operations...

headline: Management Disaster
pros: Promotes remote working, fixed working hours
cons: Archaic processes and overcomplicated management mean its virtually impossible to get anything useful done.   Too many low skilled resources from multiple competing outsourcers create a melting pot of disaster.

headline: Finance Manager
pros:
- Good benefits (life cover, childcare vouchers, bike to work ect...)
- Salary is decent, not market leading but good
- Annual leave entitlement very good 30 days + Bank Holidays
- Work life balance especially ability to work from home or use local branches 
- Good CEO, CFO and CRO, but not supported by their leadership teams to deliver change
cons:
- Bad senior management and poor executive leadership and decision making
- Staff morale is in the toilet, after numerous restructuring and cost cutting programmes which have been executed poorly with no assessment on the impact to customers and staff
- Staff seen as a cost not as a commodity
- Career progression is limited, UK back office operations are being phased out in favour of overseas hubs (India and Poland )
- Benefits are being stripped away each year to help meet the cost target
- No long term future for the organisation given it's current direction of travel
- Bank Chairman post 2008 have been anonymous (political appointments) and added no value to the organisation
- To much internal politics and fear of being seen to do something different or transformational

headline: Work only if you are in retirement mood
pros: Work life balance is good, essentially there is work only if you want to do. No bonuses, no motivations, just chill and enjoy till they shut that dept or country or use as parking place till you get better one
cons: Loss making bank. No progression at all. Bank is shutting down in many countries and shrinking in UK as well.

headline: The exodus continues in Stamford
pros: Good base salary. Generous vacation. Good work-life balance. Many people are pleasant,  friendly, and helpful. Nice office in convenient location for public transport and parking. Good amenities.
cons:
The workforce in the US has, and still is, being reduced drastically and continuously. If you look at the Warn notice list on the CT State website you will see that over the last few years and right up to the current date, they have been cutting jobs in batches of 30-50 or so typically once every month. The building was half empty when I was there and UBS has now moved into two floors. It was clear this branch had and more positive times in the past. The continuous exodus affected the behavior of staff and influenced the business decisions as people fought strategically and flexed their muscles in order to demonstrate their importance. However, there were some exceptions to the rule who just continued to roll their sleeves up and got with the job. I think there were also frustrations that cuts didn't seem to be happening in the UK offices at quite the same level as in the US, and that this was unfair. During the time I worked there management had not yet figured out a strategy on how to improve moral or provide any justifications for why staff should choose to stay.

Most of IT headcount had already been moved to lower cost centers. Typically for every one position in the US there were multiple replacements (usually about three) hired in the low cost location to equate. However, usually they were of a lower level of experience and the timezone differences and sometimes language barriers did not help. The level of knowledge and standard of work coming from the lower cost centers, with a few exceptions, was poor and in my opinion would not provide value in the long term. Many times I had to deal with support teams in other locations who did not respond, could not understand English, or did not have any technical knowledge or in fact know anything about the system or technology they were supporting. Sometimes development teams I had to work with would say "we cannot do this", even though the request was, in my opinion, not particularly technically challenging.

The level of bureaucracy was the worst I have ever witnessed. To get access to systems or to co-ordinate work with other teams took vast amounts of electronic paperwork, persistent follow-up, and escalation. The majority of emails to request access or help from other teams either went into black holes, or required persistent reminders and escalation to get actioned. To get the level of access required to do my job took several months after joining and many hours of persistent effort., and this was very frustrating. When working on projects sometimes arbitrary dates or goals were set just to please a manager or fit in with what was in a document. I think that sometimes developers and analysts lost sight of the goals they were trying to achieve, and were more focused on sticking to poorly designed project plans and arbitrary paper trails or documentation. One manager once said to me that he knows that it doesn't make sense for me to do something, but "If we need to tick a box on a document, we will". It was hard to believe that it could be any worse, but if anything required interaction with RBS Group staff or their systems then the level of bureaucracy rose to even more ridiculous levels.

For the most part, the technology stack is a little behind the times.They are one or two versions behind the latest and are still using outdated front-end technologies and frameworks. Some of the internal applications were some of the most poorly designed, bad quality user interfaces I have ever seen. Some didn't work at all, and I can't believe how they got through any QA.

There was limited budget. No travel to other offices with very few exceptions (mostly from the UK, not from the US, which caused some frustrations). Even the paper, pens, and other stationery was taken away from conference rooms, and we were told if we needed these things we needed to buy and bring our own.

There was no real work-from-home guidelines or policy and it was generally discouraged.

headline: Possibly the worst bank in the market in all respects
pros: Nothing of any consequence for prospective employees.
cons:
RBS is possibly the worst bank to work for both as an employee and shareholder. Poor management, low morale, poor bonus pool. Majority ownership by the British Government.

If you're a shareholder, you need only look at the current share price compared with the FTSE average for banking stocks.

I was embarrassed to work for this bank and was glad I left.

cons:

Lack of options to improve Technical skills as most of the technical work is done by Vendors. Permanent staff get to work mostly on process and people management.
Management is risk aversive and lacks aggressive decision making capability. Even trivial changes involve long time-consuming process and approvals.

headline: RBS GFS Roles

Best Flexibility Option - work from 8 - 5 pm or 11 to 8 pm or 12:30/1:30 - 9:30/10:30

Best for people residing in and around Gurgaon
cons:
Systems are too old and very lethargic
Too much dependency on system performance 
Your role would eventually become more of technical helpdesk as the various system in RBS are pretty old and outdated.
The adaptibility to change is missing which means even if you have some brilliant ideas , you would get a lot of resistance towards adopting the same

headline: On the right path

cons:
- Not all processes are as streamlined as they could be, so there is wastage in terms of resources and ££. Seems like we are on the way to rectifying these though
- IT systems aren't integrated very well, and could do with a lot of technology updates on internal systems.

headline: Worst Manager with worst TLs and worst team except few
pros: Voice process- handling customers queries over the phone. I never felt like working there because of the team mates.. So much hatred towards each other and there are old ill mannered employees who just don't have any senses working there and still treated like an assets. Manager why to call him Manager when he just follows the orders. I cursed myself after joining this company. TLs behaves like they have are doing favours to us. We had to think when we had to go to them ask a query because they are bloody not interested in even seeing us. I have no positive things to talk abou this company. They don't try connect with their employees and when management was meeting we had to forcefully keep our mouth shut. We at ghe end had to work under them. They can terminate someone who is interested but can't do that with someone who is just doing nothing for this company. I have so much bad things to say of this company. Never ever work in this process if asked for.
cons: Pros are my cons .. I hate the manager, TLs and old ill mannered people there

headline: Senior manager

headline: Process Associate

headline: Analyst
pros: Vacation package is extremely generous compared to other banks and 401K is at least on par with the industry. . .
cons:
Where to start... When they recruited me for the analyst role I was promised a lot. However, I ended up doing the work meant for two people because so many people have left the bank. This would normally be fine but then after working extremely hard and getting an excellent end of year review, I got no raise or bonus due to "cost cutting measures", but I was already being paid below the industry norm (This happened to everyone I spoke to). Definitely working 9 to 5 from now on.

Furthermore,  there are senior level employees who are given senior level compensation in roles that the bank doesn't need anymore. However, this isn't surprising because it seems those who underperform, or are a huge distraction and nuisance to other workers, get the same treatment as value added, hardworking employees. 

Everyone here is just counting down the days until they can find a new job - except for the overpaid senior execs who get awarded all of the bonus money for the hard work everyone below them does.

headline: Pmo lead
pros: Easy interview process, smooth agency checks and reference checks

Dreadful IT facilities

Floor plans for desks aren't accurate
Only a handful of desks with 2 screens
Dreadful politics
Too much emphasis on formatting of appendices on packs. No one reads them!
Over fifty stakeholders from around the world dial into a weekly meeting and recording the attendees is a fairly unfruitful, thankless task.
Security treat contractors like criminals by constantly checking their passes.
Been asked to work for that company again, but I cannot risk my sanity.

headline: Working at RBS
pros: Excellent working conditions within Operations
cons: Frequent management changes at senior level

headline: Business development
pros: Good people. Average money. Should listen to staff a lot more. As some have proven to be very successful else where!
cons: Where to start. Want us to work 24 hours 7 days a week with also skipping lunch. Many many meetings a day to which are not informative.

headline: Senior Analyst Quant
pros: Very chilled out place, flexi hours, good perks

headline: Good place to start a career

cons: Compensation & Benefits, Employee retention

headline: Commercial Banking
pros: Great other interns, given a lot to do while on the ten weeks.
cons: Grad role is not completely in London, 4 rotations, one of which will be outside of London, issue for those who don't like moving locations for 6 months, Salary for Grad scheme low compared to others.

headline: Ok type company to work
pros: nice food and people are technical even higher management are technical
cons: only interview process is tough , technical work less than what is desired at a time of interview

headline: Ok Experience
pros: Work Environment is excellent, you get to socialize and meet people from global offices, co workers are friendly too
cons: Quality of Work is pathetic. things were better off if not done, capability and maturity with underlying concepts is missing

headline: Good pay for customer service job
pros:
- good wage, especially for student working part time
- good scope for progression
- lots of events to get staff motivated
- very flexible with shifts
cons:
- call centre environment is very repetitive and restrictive because everything is so closely monitored. 
- weekend work is mandatory for part time staff

headline: vice president, development
pros: Work life balance is awesome because of fixed timing culture.
cons: Going through tough time because of heavy losses and fines.

headline: RBS IDC : Software Engineer
pros:
I have been working with RBS since 5yr. 3 different teams 5 different managers.
Till 2013 the company kept its standard good people, mixed kind of management. But after certain time lower and middle level management turned out to be sloths turning this company from tech and innovated oriented to a support oriented. Most of the dev related  job are either is of low quality or support. Most of good players of rbs idc had left or leaving. So coming to pros

good HR policies (cab food etc)
good to work for people who does not want new learning and want to settle for repetitive activity for long duration.
Best company for managers, you are the king - HR has no powers, manager decision is final.
cons:
Job quality
Hr has no power to protect human values or employee concerns.
Manager oriented company, where if a zaroo marne wala becomes manager there is nothing you can do about it.
Lower and middle level manager has no skills they are sloths and will make you from an tech and innovation oriented person to slave(I have worked with 5 managers and there upper levels)
No Innovation is promoted or recognize where as a Hippocratic agenda lower level management show that they push people for innovation in meetings. Where as they want to work you as slaves for 24 *7 when ever they ask(I was asked to work on uat issue at 2 am several times)
Highly political environment.
 If you are innovative and try to implement new things or process no one is there to listen or support, do it on you time.OHHH you will be asked there to sit for long hr and some time manager can say why dude polluting company culture and work life balance. Funny , happens with me with 3 managers.
HR is there to do paper works.
Whole management has a group of network across RBS and they support each other(As they have settled down from several yr) there is no place for employee to go if they re tortured.(Once I have to threatened my manager to take him to court when he asked me to work like slave for several time and with a very rude tone)

headline: Excellent Organization
pros:
good work culture
Flexible working hours
Good people
cons: Nothing to say much about this

headline: Average working experience
pros:
Good platform for freshers.
Some process are really good like GTS, AML etc.
Plenty of leaves.
cons:
Monotonous work, no challenges.
No transparency in IJPs, mostly people who clear IJP by flattering and buttering their managers.
Manager cares very less for employees personal growth
Less learning opportunity.
Low salary.
You wont get leaves when you need them.
Mismanaged transportation system

headline: Kyc
pros: If there were any, I would surely have listed them
cons: You're not credited for your work. Horrible atmosphere

headline: Good work environment
pros: work life balance,ggod environment, good exposure,

headline: good for long term
pros: good for long term, good salary , food, transport, leave etc

headline: Summer Internship
pros:
- Friendly and supportive environment
- Comprehensive induction week 
- Given real responsibilities with a steep learning curve
cons:
- Experience varies from department to department (some teams tend to be slacker than others)
- Redundant and repetitive events

headline: Good for starting

Nice people
Excellent work life balance
cons: Management do not value proactiveness and actively stifle proactivity

headline: Government company!

headline: RBS Finance - US

headline: RBS quant job
pros: Nice benefits, very nice work environment, relatively relaxed atmostphere
cons: A few smart people, but a bit too few. Managers selected in an inbred way

headline: Mixed reactions....!!!!
pros:
Here are some pros that are really essential to know:
1. Free cab (Home pickup/drop)
2. Free Meals- Lunch and Dinner ( if you want to work longer)
3. Good salary hikes
4. Performance bonus (year end)
5. Work life balance
cons:
1. Favoritism culture
2. Focus is on being highlighted, your work is not seen, only you stardom is seen

headline: Good place to live life but work can be a question to ponder upon
pros: Good culture, respectful company, good food and pleasant environment.
cons: Work can be irregular at time. Technology wise RBS is way behind and still uses old tool and can reduce work efficiency at times.

headline: Friendly and surprisingly well run
pros:
I worked in technology in the investment bank, which is very different to the retail bank.

It has a very positive working environment.  For the most part, people are friendly, concerned about welfare, and genuinely care.  It's also surprisingly efficient (by the standards of a large bank which isn't saying too much).
cons: Morale in the investment bank has been in freefall for a number of years as continuous costcutting and reduction in scope have bitten.

headline: my review
pros: Nice work culture in cpy
cons: Far from my place at cp

headline: Working at RBS
pros: Flexible Working, flexible salary package, working from home.
cons: Under a constant threat of restructure / redundancy.

headline: Commercial Banking Summer Internship
pros: Goos exposure to the whole of the business and senior business people. Lots of opportunities to meet other people and network.
cons: Workplace was not challenging and dull at times. Did not seem to be a complete set of tasks for interns to complete.

headline: NA
pros: Good work life balance, NA
cons: policies sucks and nothing much

headline: Poor management
pros: Work life balance, Additional benefits, excellent people who strive against the odds to service the customers
cons: Poor mid and high level and senior management promoted from within who know very little other than banking and promoted because of who they know - drinking culture and back slapping. Poor appraisal system. Process driven and lots of bureaucracy - difficult to get things done. Lateral thinking and vision not encouraged - too many yes men who play the game. Senior management have no clue of whats going on at the coalface. Customers not put first - one scandal after another. IT poor, staff facilities poor - takes ages to get anything done, now very focused on box ticking to cover peoples backs instead of looking after customers. Buzz words and initiatives which achieve nothing, constant changes of exco and restructuring. Poor morale and public image. Embarassing to work for. Top heavy at head office level. Uncompetitive, poor products, sales culture still evident although denied, numbers driven and dependent on if your face fits and nodding donkeys.

headline: Not quite what it was
pros: Flexibility in terms of home or office working, decent work/life balance.
cons: Continual downsizing, lack of job security.  Not much of a "team spirit" in recent years, all feels a bit artificial.

headline: Developer
pros: Great work life balance, Good team, new technology to learn
cons: less growth, higher management is not taking care.

headline: One of the best Employee friendly
pros: Work life balance,Hub of knowledge,Best in trainings that will help you to grow in career.
cons: Pay less and almost zero opportunity to work in abroad or Training

headline: Good Place to Work
pros: Employee friendly policies like food & transport. Good Pay structure.
cons: A bit of red-tapism may at times be demoralizing.

headline: ok-ok
pros: Work life balance is best..numbers of leaves which they provide and sick leave accumulation policy is best
cons: old systems, some people dont want to move ahead and dont allow any1 else as well to move ahead

headline: Process Associate
pros: Good start, hand on experience, cab facility, free meals.
cons: Low pay, some work hours are at odd timings, no growth for those who only have undergraduate degree.

headline: Graduate Trainee
pros: Interesting people to work with and quasi-challenging environment.
cons: Working in a dysfunctional firm is very demotivating.

headline: Good place to start
pros: Nice and friendly working environment. Very good place to start for getting experience and enriching your CV. Not too hard to get in if you know languages well.
cons: Salary not at all competitive with other Warsaw-based companies. Job description not too exciting, tending to repetitive/boring. Not too much attention on individual needs from upper management.

headline: No work life balance

Used to be good not any more
Brand name
Travel facility is good
Provides food
cons:
No worklife balance
Managers lack leadership qualities
As company in loss no increments
Needs more man power
People are leaving the organization

headline: RBS
pros: Interesting and challenging work. Good client base, lots of career and growth opportunities with further ways to get involved with projects and other work outside your remit. Very good work life balance with only 35 contracted hours per week.
cons: I found there to be a great deal of bureaucracy with so much emphasis on compliance, policies and procedures, reporting and box ticking that it made it difficult to service client to best of my ability.

headline: VP in Technology
pros: Great people to work with.. Very relaxed working environment and good benefits
cons:
No raises or bonuses for 5 years and counting..
Need to start increasing salaries or good people will be gone soon

headline: Associate II
pros: Employee friendly company, Good employee services, Good ambiance with good exposure
cons: Can work on more employee satisfaction HR services and providing employees more career opportunities

headline: Reporting manager
