cons: Often takes a long time to get things done or to find the right people who can help particularly around systems etc..

headline: Senior FINREP financial reporting analyst
pros: slowly trying to catch up the fact it's already passed 2003...
cons: where do i start, management style, system were all so old school.

headline: One of the best place to work
pros: Employee friendly organization, work from home availability, general shift timings, good infrastructure, awesome food and transport facilities, healthy work culture and environment, good management and leadership, qualified staff
cons: quality of work is not appropriate as per individual's qualification and expectation. people can be utilized more as there is availability of time within normal working hrs

headline: Junior Financial Analyst
pros: company has a rule of work/ life balance
cons:
personal development very limited
lack of new opprotunities
work is very repetitive without new challenges

headline: Sad
pros:
This list of "Pros" does not apply to all, but for a majority of the employees, it can be assumed as True:
1) 8am-5pm work
2) Cab
3) Subsidized food (the quality is a big question though)
cons:
1) Lots of dirty politics
2) Lazy people only need to butter up their bosses to stay permanently in the org
3) No promotions/hikes for deserving employees.
4) As good as no bonuses
5) continuously changing management/policies
6) biased managers (they prefer to hire/promote ppl of their own kind)
7) no HR presence

headline: Good work place
pros: Best working environment. Given the opportunity in future i will like to work there again.
cons: It is a good place to work but the contract is short

headline: Lot of Office Politics
pros: Facilities, Salary and Work Life Balance
cons: Managers play divide and rule, promote their favourites, Unfair reviews

headline: Commercial Banking
pros: Friendly staff, open to answering your questions and give constructive feedback when assessing your progress.
cons: Very little work given to do. Didn't feel that internship was particularly well organised. Little notice given to your preference on location.

headline: Mortgage Customer Care Agent
pros: Very supportive. Flexible benefits package and access to development, support and training to further career certifications. Open line of communication.
cons: Salary could be higher though.

headline: analyst
pros: Work environment, culture, values, additional beenefits
cons: very low salary and tough evaluation procedure

headline: Spring Intern
pros: Open working concept and friendly culture
cons: Technology could do with some improvements

headline: Shrinking presence outside UK
pros: Good work life balance. Generally nice people. Great building and amenities, good location.
cons: Government ownership directs management to make poor decisions. Massive scale reduction in US. Limited opportunities for growth at the moment.

headline: Good company
pros: Good Training, Nice colleagues
cons: I would have like to learn more.

headline: Telephone Customer Service Rep
pros:
I was only there for a short period of time, I had not even completed my training. Unfortunately, I had to leave after 3-4 weeks of employment as I had to prioritise other committments. 
Although, whilst I was there, I really enjoyed it! The work ethic is great! people are really friendly, the managers were really understanding and helpful and tbh I had great fun! NOTHING like other call centres which I have worked for! I was gutted that I had to leave.
cons: The only downside I could possibly think of is the hours. The hours were not fixed and your weekly rota will be constantly changing. Although this was discussed during the interview stages. Also, I was disspointed to find out that the graduate scheme had been stopped.

headline: VP
pros: still a good fixed income and fx business
cons: unstable due to bank restructuring and people moving around

headline: Associate
pros: work life balance is there
cons: pay structure is not that good

headline: RBS
pros: flexible hours, good atmosphere, nice medical package
cons: generally mess, lack of consistency in action / strategy

headline: Poor Salaries
pros: Good brand name Good brand name Good brand name
cons: Too relaxed environment Good brand name Good brand name Good brand name

headline: Cash Handler
pros: The team were great to work with
cons: the hours were not great

headline: RBS Review
pros: Good culture given the troubles that RBS has been through
cons: HR are too dependent on pushing for the goals when this may cause bad practices

headline: Excellent Opportunities
pros: Excellent Opportunities to explore the bank, from presentations, networking events to work-shadowing in various divisions, especially at Coutts.
cons: Culture too laid back and relaxed for my liking. No specific division for investment banking, mainly risk management, fixed income trading and debt capital markets.

headline: Vice President
pros: Fairly good benefits with medical, dental and vision care.  The paycheck deductions increased yearly while benefits decreased.  They did have a profit sharing at the time ong with bonus which was rare at time.
cons: Bank senior management really did little to mitigate the risks in mbs and debt obligations products.  When they secured their bailout from the BOE, instead of cutting and review profitable business lines, the culture was such that nothing was wrong.  Staff continued to fly around the world, wasting capital resources when a video conference call would do.

headline: Senior Director
pros: Coming to the end of the turnaround story
cons: Still under Government ownership impacting flexibility

headline: OK place to work
pros:
Was paid quite high base pay (which included fixed allowance)
Relaxed working environment. Rarely stayed beyond 6pm
Flexible working, working from home was fine.
cons:
Job security, constant layoffs due to exits from products or markets
Low morale due to redundancies. Salary was kept constant.  
Technology was outdated

headline: Good Culture
pros:
Free cab, lunch and dinner.
Good food
Ample leaves
cons:
Unstable
No quality work
Poor IT support
No body wants to work
No learning

headline: Some green shoots but a long time to harvest
pros:
There are some signs of improvement, the realisation (that took 5 years and a change of CEO) that employees matter is the biggest change.
The investment in training leaders to lead is very welcome
cons:
Too many of the 'old' behaviours are still in place.
A lot of people only paying lip service to the new agenda, bullying is still happening.
Too much change in a short period, change needs to be embedded.
Tendency to bring in contract staff rather than promote from within.
Offshoring is not working - loss of experienced staff, for supposedly cheaper substitutes has harmed the IT systems. If it takes four times as many people twice a long to do a job, the Bank does not save money. 
Lack of career progression
Pay is no longer competitive

headline: Good work enviornment
pros:
Good work enviornment
good pay and other facility
cons: not many area to change techlogy

headline: Telephony Customer Advisor
pros: Fun, Fast paced and flexible. Good working hours and amazing team mates.
cons: Pay isn't the best compared to other banks and a lot of last minute scheduling changes.

headline: challenging and rewarding
pros: audit team is relatively new and still maturing.  Plenty of opportunity to shine and develop new and efficient ways of working.  High volume of change in the business means plans and work change frequently, the audit assignments vary from a few weeks to many months, and include internal advisory as well as traditional risk-based.
cons: rather more politics than I was expecting.  High volume of change in the business means plans often change.  relatively high turnover of staff means more time spent recruiting and on training up, rather than developing long term, for staff

headline: Mainframe Professional with 13 yrs of IT Experience
pros:
Great Work Life Balance
Decent Salary
cons:
Promotions are not straightforward
The career growth in Managerial stream (Team Lead to Project Manager )is clear
The career growth in Technology stream ( Tech Lead to Architect) is practically non-existent for mainframe profsessionals.

headline: Royal Bank of Scotland
pros: Good work life balance, good training support
cons: Compensation is low but the benefit are good.

headline: Summer Intern - Asset Finance
pros: Good development opportunities and very supportive workplace
cons: Sometimes felt like there wasn't enough work to do

headline: Operations Analyst
pros: Great environment,  Work/life balance, good training
cons: Too many layoffs, No salary increase

headline: Assistant Director
pros:
Great people - good working atmosphere
Pay reasonable (not the best in the market)
Starting to move beyond the chaos of the post 2008 period
A job without any strain or personal development (assuming you see that as a plus... I did not)
cons:
Initiative heavy management focus - all ideas and no delivery of anything of actual use to employees
Shrinking bank with shrinking ambition
Too many "job for life" roles and people

headline: Great culture, great work life balance, great opportunities
pros: I have worked here for 13 years and have really enjoyed it. Lots of opportunities, work from home 2 days a week, I buy a weeks extra holiday each year...so I have 35 days holiday. You get 3 days to use on charitable events. Maternity package is 3 months full pay. The company is investing a lot into its leadership and gender programmes. Lots of learning and development. Mentoring. Very supportive culture.
cons: I suppose I would only say that as the company is very large, you will have very different experiences depending on where you are...and who your line manager is. I have been very lucky with my managers.

headline: Market Risk Associate
pros: Friendly people, generally jerks free environment within Risk. Generally encourage secondments to learn about what the other departments do. Weekly conference calls with risk managers describing what they do,  challenges they face, etc.
cons: The role was in London. Cost of living was insane.

headline: Fair Company in light of it's current financial situation
pros:
The culture and financial position of RBS has changed pretty significantly over the past few years.   Despite this fact, RBS still tries to stay open and transparent with their employees about upcoming events and changes in the direction of the firm.

Despite the rising costs, RBS has been able to maintain pretty comprehensive benefits packages.

The building is in a very convenient location for employees who drive as well as train commuters ( the building is across the street from the Stamford station ).
There is a Gym and a Cafe on site.
cons: It's hard to keep up with all of the changes in head count and responsibilities for the people who stay with the firm.  The cafeteria isn't the best, there's a noticeable lack of food selections.

headline: Business Adviser - Direct Business Banking MCR
pros: None at all, not even the money.
cons:
High staff turnover
Crap Training
Uneducated Managers and senior management
No sense of direction

headline: Good company, weak management
pros: Treats employees very well. Good systems and exposure for employees. Used to be a good pay master till the time bad fortunes hit the company.
cons: Lacks transparency. Lacks direction in business. There is no long term thinking at management level. The strategy decided more in reactive manner.

headline: Client Service
pros: No pros at this point given the situation
cons: Currently winding down operations so job opportunities are not good

headline: Customer service advisor
pros: Lovely people, great hours, flexible
cons: Wages are not great and training

headline: Good company to start with
pros: Good work life balance, Brand Name, Honest Company
cons: Companies profits at least in India are declining , hence no more scope for long years

headline: Benefits
pros: Excellent staff, career opportunities, great work,life balance
cons: Not applicable to comment on

headline: RBS
pros: Money is ok, you meet some fantastic people, always job opportunities and possibility to transfer, they got free hot drinks machines, overtime
cons: a culture of fear, you have to be cold to move up, policies keep changing like the wind, a culture of fear, you have to be cold to move up, policies keep changing like the wind,

headline: RBS
pros: I worked with some great folk and made many good friends as a result.
cons: Too focused on getting the numbers instead of doing the right thing for the customers.

headline: Most unhappy place to work.
pros: It is a job if that is all you are looking for.
cons: This is not a recommended place to work. Moral is extremely low. Management don't make good decisions.  Pay is low.

headline: "Good company to work for..!!!!"
pros:
Good Work life balance.
Free cab and food with negligible charges.
Good infrastructure.
cons:
No-Onsite opportunities.
Work is good only in some projects , tool and technology are too old.
Lack of Technical folks around you and no body is interested in technical discussions.
Good for Experience candidate who just wanted to manage their family and want to maintain work life balance.

headline: Perfect
pros:
Nice worklife Balance
Paid is g8 bas per the market Standards
Very nice work Environment
Maintain good facility
cons:
Very slow Promotion
No growth interms of vertical level

headline: Process
pros: its a great place to work
cons: there nothing to share about

headline: Employee friendly
pros:
Good work life balance - Lots of leaves and work from home (depends on manager)
Very good work (depends on department)
Still a good paymaster and Free cab & lunch in NCR
cons:
No long term vision by leaders
Promotion depends majorly on your supervisor and department head
Job security is an issue as RBS is exiting from multiple geographies

headline: Not for high achievers
pros: Nice building.  Decent benefits.  Continued massive layoffs may actually help turn around the business, if you happen to be one of the few who survive.
cons: Culture of mediocrity.  Stuck in meetings all day where nothing gets accomplished.  Constantly changing management where people are shuffled around internally but have no specific experience with the processes their new group handles.

headline: Risk Graduate scheme
pros: Good opportunity to be based outside of London. Spent 6 months in Edinburgh
cons: Long hours and not a lot of training

headline: Senior Software Designer
pros: Office time 8 to 5 and cab facility lures most of employees.
cons: Slow growth as job iteration rate is less and most of the employee are from Delhi/NCR local. These cause highly political  environment and lead to undue competition.

headline: Good organization to work with
pros:
Good work life balance. i.e. sufficient no. of leaves.
Good food.
Good cab service
Remuneration is a bit above of service based industries.
Bonus is above your total fixed package
cons:
Very less or almost nothing w.r.t onsite opportunities.
Internal politics is on a high.
Manager's favouritism in rating system.

headline: tfiu
pros: good in leaves, cab picks n drop facility, good work life balance
cons: too much cost cutting.. too much politics

headline: Risk and Control Manager
pros: Great Opportunities given the reduction in work force if you are one to be persistent and look for every opportunity possible.
cons: Moral as a whole was bad given the constant reduction in workforce and foot print in the Stamford office. Lack of trust in employees by senior management.

headline: Be careful of the outlook
pros: Good compensation in the market
cons: US business and presence shrinks

headline: Too much bureaucracy
pros: Good pay, Incentives and Benefits
cons: Politics, Bureaucracy. Ideas and comments from lower staff are not even considered or even heard !

headline: Awful
pros: Absolutely none at all. Don't work here.
cons: Steadily eroding benefits. Branch staff treated poorly and neglected whilst being told of the importance of the retail bank.

headline: London Banking Graduate Programme Review
pros:
1. The programme starts with 4 rotations each 6 months at 4 different desks, giving the opportunity to experience different areas of investment banking

2. Good training programme, both technical and soft skills

3. RBS is known as having better "culture" than almost all other investment banks
cons:
1. Biggest 'con' - pay; due to the known high publicity RBS bonuses receive, bonuses are non-existent at RBS when compared to other investment banks (a partial but not definitely not sufficient compensation is the fact that base pay is quite good)

2. Bureaucracy - RBS is a very bureaucratic place, both due to the fact that it is a large organisation and due to the company specific history; as a result, multiple people from Analyst to MD spend a lot of time in box-checking exercises

headline: good place to learn domain
pros: Good work life balance and transparent policy
cons: needs decentralised work culture at every level and unit.

headline: Former RBS employee
pros: Used to be known for it's culture, which is not an attractor anymore.
cons: Too much bureaucracy. Bad management.

headline: encourage
pros: working with UK and Indian shifts and work to hard
cons: dedicate to work company not for salary

headline: Architects In RBS, Gurgaon
pros: Wide variety of applications. The gamut itself is an open field invitation to explore. This is where you learn 'Enterprise Architecture'.
cons:
Architects loose their shine once the product is stabilised. No new product ideas - live with whatever you have - kind of stagnates after a while. 

Too verbose - people sell themselves in various ways within the company just not work. 

Some misbalances between India and UK.

headline: Business Analyst
pros: Work life balance is at its best.
cons: Too much of bureaucracy for internal processes

headline: RBS Light
pros: Great benefits. Final salary pension, DIS Life cover, Massive discounts on Health Care, Child Care etc.  Used to have a good work environment.
cons: Complete lack of strategy and an egotistical approach to risk destroyed what was once a fantastic company. No profit share bonus or annual bonus for the average worker but the Directors who ruined the company ( some of them still work there ) still get their massive pensions and bonuses.

headline: Too slow an organisation
pros: The bank has good work life balance and the trains the incomers well enough to be able to join the role
cons: The bank is wrapping up the operations in Asia due to poor profitability and declining revenues

headline: generic
pros: good work life balance, fair management. you need to understand the process that they have to adhere to for promotions, appraisals etc and act to leverage their power.
cons: less experienced people are earning more as they bargain at the time of joining, they get good role as well. existing employees have to bear that loss.

headline: Overall Rating
pros: Good benefits, great atmosphere, opportunities for advancement
cons: No bonus, small increase in pay raise

headline: Operations
pros: Nice people, good opportunities. Joined the company in November 2013. Learned a lot since and made some good friends too
cons: Not anything important to mention. It's a great environment to work in

headline: Not for the feint hearted
pros:
Great people, a real Dunkirk spirit in the face of adversity.
Generous holiday allowance
Flexible working (at line manager discretion)
cons:
Below market rate remuneration
Constant change in the form of structural reorganisations - sometimes multiple restructures in a 12 month period.  Makes career progression difficult to plan beyond the upcoming 6 month period.   The upside of constant change is contant career opportunity.

headline: Head Branch Banking
pros: Wonderful working atmosphere, great peers and the company gives working space for an individual to work on an entrepreneurial format
cons: Because of the global meltdown, India operations also curtailed

headline: process associate
pros: Work pressure is not much.
cons:
Very slow growth and restricted to your business unit
Compensation is not as per the industry.

headline: Good company to work in
pros: RBS has great development process among all the banks (I have worked in few till now).
cons: Salary is average and at par with industry standard

headline: Managing Director
pros: Genuinely smart and good people there but highly dependent on the division and department.
cons: Poorly managed strategically leading leading up to the financial crisis.  Failure of RBS in 2008 led to overall strategic reset, but implementation too slow.  Continual restructurings and changes in overall direction in the years following created an extremely difficult and uncertain work environment.

headline: Average.
pros:
relaxed working atmosphere.
relaxed management style
encourages indépendant working.
cons:
low pay compared to neighbouring institutes. 
career paths are unclear

headline: Internship
pros:
They invested a lot of time in you
You were thrown right into the heart of everything

headline: Overwhelming mediocre culture with everyone being very proud of futile stuff ther are doing
pros: Salary, work life balance, free cab , food thats pretty much it. If you want to give time to your family this is the company lol
cons:
1. New joiners are not at all welcomed, be ready for lone lunches 
2. Onboarding process is not at all helpful,so during first few days fight for the access card and portal accesses
3. Technologies are old, interview process doesn't match with the job. Interview is so hard and the work can be done by a simple graduate.
4. People are very cold and do not share info. They try to maintain dependency i guess.
5. People are especially proud of i dont know what and would not even reply to your hi or hello
6. Not introduced to whole team so whenever you have some work you introduce yourself to the person and then you are on his mercy if he helps you or not.
7. You dont take breaks between work but you work between breaks.
8. There is a lot of seat crunch and your system will be removed without your permission.
9. Work is last priority processes are long and old.
Its been few weeks i joined and it doesnot feel good except for the salary.

headline: Great Learning experience

headline: Unrealistic expectations
pros: There are some excellent people here but in Technology the phrase 'lions led by donkeys' would seem to apply.
cons:
Working in RBS Technology Services department is frustrating, to say the least. There are hundreds of legacy mainframe systems handling trillions of pounds worth of transactions each day yet management seem to think that these can be remediated or enhanced in short order. Many projects are initiated with 'aggressive deadlines' but then run into difficulty because of a lack of experienced staff. Third party suppliers are then brought in to 'help' but they usually lack skills and experience and need hand-holding all the way from when they arrive to when they leave.
To work here you need a combination of skills from nursery assistant through to technical specialist because those are the range of jobs you'll be doing.

headline: Don't even think of it!
pros:
Corporate & Institutional Banking (CIB):

- Very good work life balance (this is one of the main reasons why many people stick around)
- Offers good domain exposure e.g. Investment Banking, Payments etc.
- Offers challenges pertaining to managing legacy systems & their decommissioning, large number of interdependent systems
- Work flexibility (from home or in different timings as suitable), free transport, food, baby creche
- Air travel (international) entitlement by business class for _all_ employees
- Clean pay structure (all fixed, no variable component - bonus is discretionary)
cons:
Corporate & Institutional Banking (CIB):

- HR merely exists & there are very limited touch points (all you do is call a helpline no. & speak over the phone like a call center). 
- The bank is going through immense restructuring & turbulent times (shareholders pressure) & is expected to last until 2020.
- Mostly regulatory, mandatory or BAU work, not really much to innovate. Budgets are majorly impacted due to pressure from shareholders & annual fines.
- Pace of change due to legacy platforms is too slow due to lack of knowledge & interdependency across systems. Most of the SMEs have left the organization & others have moved across to other platforms internally. Hence, adequate knowledge of the product across team remains to be insufficient.
- Most of the long term plans (1.5 - 2 yrs+) often get derailed or de-prioritized. It's mostly a norm than exception & have witnessed it for at least 5 years. As a result, lot of capital is drained without significant ROI.
- Change in leadership & significant restructuring happens too often (twice every year). Hence, the after effects or problems arising from actions/decisions of the earlier management falls on the new leadership team who would naturally not take any accountability. New leadership team has it's own vision & priorities which is much different from earlier one. Hence, it's an easy excuse for everyone & no one is penalized.
- Since organization is getting shorter every year the pace of change is very high which the leadership team isn't able to manage effectively. This effects annual appraisals, promotions & other incentives for those below.
- Most of the good staff has left (at all levels). A good percentage of those who remain (especially at higher positions) are not very capable but would naturally stick around. Naturally, it's an easy guess what the next leadership layer would be.

headline: Better than you would expect
pros: Mostly great people who are focused on doing the right thing, despite all that is said in the press, some fantastic brands/customer franchises, a sense that things are moving in the right direction and the ability to be part of that, generally good work-life balance and very open to flexibility (although that can be dependent on where you work), internal mobility has a high priority, good benefits
cons: Trying to implement 'one size fits all' policies/processes etc across all the different parts of the Bank can sometimes mean that they are only adequate (or sometimes not even that) for everyone. There are pockets where some of the leadership cannot make/implement difficult decisions or have difficult conversations

headline: Average company to work for, poor leadership
pros: good salaries and benefits packages, fairly stable jobs, fair treatment of employees during lay-offs. Good place to work if you are a c-player - avoid too much thinking, do minimum to keep the job and do what you're told - you'll get recognized for that and even promoted on occassion. B-players doing some independent thinking may find this place good to work for in some very specific areas where the company really needs expertise and someone experienced to take the steer. A-players have nothing to look for here, they would simply stand out too much from the crowd and go against the company culture.
cons: poor leadership and communication with staff (you can learn more about what's going within the company from the news), very UK-centric and not truly international (visible discrimination at almost every level), low maturity of business processes and organisation, strongly political environment, technologically backwards

headline: Debt Management & Operations
pros: Good promotion of team working. The people I worked with often made the job. Opportunities to advance. Pension provision and salary packages good relative to industry averages. Structured training.  Great emphasis on putting the customer first.
cons: Increased rationalisation meant many experienced staff were lost to the competition. Policy to recruit agency staff at entry level meant attrition relatively high. Investing a lot of time and money re-training or employing contractors at high rates of pay. Staff benefits packages eroded over recent years.

headline: Getting better
pros: The culture is pleasant with flat hierarchy in the most part. Hours are decent and senior management generally do care about staff needs.
cons:
Pay is weak outside the investment bank, though they will pay new joiners market rate you will barely increase afterwards. In a shrinking bank promotion chances are tight and development opportunities in some areas are hard to come by. Systems are very weak.
The biggest issue is many staff have been through such tough years the feeling is jaded and flat in many areas, weary resignation rather than annoyance at issues faced and constant restructuring and down sizing.

headline: Still a company in turmoil
pros: Conveniently located offices in central London, supportive colleagues, actively encouraged to work from home, good networking opportunities and possible charity involvement or sponsorship
cons: Poor man management skills within the management team, high proportion of contract staff to permanent - 70% contract staff was the figure I heard, lack of joined up thinking with new initiatives - lots of enthusiasm but no substance.  Outdated technology.  Too many people are having to work too many hours just to keep things on track.

headline: Working for RBS Markets and International Banking division
pros:
- Strong camaraderie amongst the people 
- Working hours fairly relaxed with 8am-5:30pm being the norm for most
- Colleagues are high caliber always willing to share and invest time educating others
- Market perception of RBS talent pool remains positive offering strong branding for employees
cons:
- Business is contracting from an international platform to a UK retail focused bank with limited scope for career opportunities outside the UK market.
- UK government ownership continues to weigh on management adding to what is already a highly political organization 
- Limited transparency around vision of the bank and lack of empowerment amongst management 
- Doing deals is hard... Central based Compliance, legal and risk functions dictate the banks willingness to do deals in-spite of strong business justifications. The bank is focused on reducing RWA's, freeing-up capital and reducing risk exposures, making the conventional deal-making process challenging and long-winded
- No bonus culture at all

headline: Byzantine, bureaucratic, backward, and abominably boring.
pros: They pay on time.  They have lots of financial (and therefore other) resources.
cons: The most talented people mostly left in the aftermath of the financial crisis.  The folks who are still there a hanging on to earn a paycheck.  Internal communication is extremely poor - especially across divisions.  Management is ossified.  Decision-making is slow; often, no one wants to go out on a limb for fear of being wrong.  Their technology stack is irretrievably backward.

headline: Good Bank to work for, pays well, good work life balance though a bit conservative.

3. Fast Cycles of DEV. 2-4 weeks of Agile Sprint.
cons:
1. very Conservative org
2. Pay is less compared to other banks.

headline: Sinking ship in Asia
pros: There are no pros worth listing

Reorganisations have been constant and regular feature for a number of years since the big bailout.

headline: The experience at RBS has been  good and satisfying.

headline: Good employer but struggling with past baggage, large restructure and retraction to being UK centric.
pros: Pay is OK, flexible working and work from home, generally nice people.
cons:
Staff are too thinly spread, reliance on offshore resources of varying quality, management - PMs and delivery managers are overworked and imo struggle to do devote enough time to important stuff like people management and career development of their staff, the senior ones are generally invisible.

Would not really recommend people starting out in IT to come to RBS. Compensation isn't high enough at the managerial level vs senior a/p or tech specialist to justify the extra responsibility. Also, if you want to advance to management and are in the final salary pension, there's a huge disincentive due to the capping in place - you'd need to look at money purchase I believe

I have been working in RBS for more than 3 years, but every time i work my best but the company could not pay ur efforts & work then i think company doesnot deserve the best employees or Best Employer Reward..

headline: Some good people to work with, but far too much talk and not enough action.
pros:
Learn how to 'play the game' and you can go far.
Work life balance is good if you can convince your manager that you work hard.
Easy to stand out from the crowd if you are skilled.
Pay is good if you are hired externally.
Flexible working good if your manager isn't old school.
cons:
Recent restructure is very bad news. New management claims that the organisation is to become more horizontal, but it has gone the complete opposite direction. Extremely top heavy, and it's getting worse.
Way too many new managers who love to spend all day "discussing" and "having a think about...", but ultimately don't have a clue how to execute and play it all by ear. When things succeed, they take the credit, when they don't, they will happily shift blame to their more junior staff.
Managers are terrible at differentiating between the fakers vs people with real talent.
Pay is extremely inconsistent within grade bands, and will take a very long time to rectify naturally due to HR policies.
If you get promoted, expect a very disappointing pay rise (if at all).
The old "retail banking" culture is starting to take over the whole bank. Very narrow minded way of thinking with little common sense, blindly establishing and following procedures with no appetite for creative thinking.

headline: Long way to go
pros: Work can be varied and interesting. Money is decent and benefits are all good. A good work life balance and good colleagues
cons: Management are under pressure to achieve sales targets which filters all the way down who seem to encounter even greater pressure and threat of redundancy.

headline: Extremely political organisation

headline: Organisation climate affected by the crisis events and the aftermath as nationalised institution
pros: Everything good that's valid for all banks: decent remuneration and benefits, relative stability and internal career progress paths at low and middle levels.
cons: Everything bad that's valid for all banks: corporate intrigue and mistrust, backstabbing, politics... Potential for staff exploitation and overwork with disastrous impact on personal life and health. All this exacerbated by continuing uncertainty about the Bank's future, need for cost-cutting and redundancies to reduce losses, need to (promptly!) repay the Taxpayer, meddling by politicians etc etc. Very unhealthy climate has changed everyone's behaviour and it's definitely not a fun place to work. One can still earn good money - being prepared to play political games and sacrifice some integrity and some health.

headline: Over 2 years
pros:
Same as for every large organisation: lots of various jobs available, and as professionalisation of functions is not high, it is often easy to get into something you have never done before. Current restructuring although a negative force in general is still creating new teams and opportunities.
Agile working ie people working from home Friday or more often is also a positive
cons:
Restructuring = Massive layoffs. That says it all. Good people left through voluntary and sometimes not redundancy.
The chaos this was designed to eliminate continues though

headline: Dont do it

If you like keeping your head in the sand, knowingly producing mediocre, sub standard results and can turn a blind eye to the $000 being thrown at lazy consultants and plaster on a bleeding wound solutions then this is the place for you. If the general public really understood the prevalent mismanagement and incompetency that oozes from the walls at RBS there would be riots on the streets of Bishopsgate.
A bunch of very nice decent people can be found throughout the halls but nice does not equate an efficiently run bank and these above are definitely in the minority.
cons:
If you like keeping your head in the sand, knowingly producing mediocre, sub standard results and can turn a blind eye to the $000 being thrown at lazy consultants and plaster on a bleeding wound solutions then this is the place for you. headline: Political football

Three major changes of strategy in the past 3 years, first dropping equities trading business then retail products then any geography outside UK, Core Europe and US. The COO office has grown rather than shrunk throughout these changes,  with the addition of more and more strategy staff in addition to the inevitable increase in compliance staff. The result is that fewer sales and trading staff need to produce revenue to support more and more middle office staff.

headline: Sad the downward spiral that this organisation has taken
pros:
Flexible working patterns are now policy, to save office space and associated infrastructure costs it is now possible to work from home using your own devices.

There are still some great people who are working in this organisation.

The new corporate values.

Some of the office accommodation (Gogarburn) is of high quality.
cons:
Since the financial crash this organisation has changed from the best place I have worked when I really felt valued and appreciated and was able to do a good job to a place where there is bullying and obstacles are put in the way of getting a good job done - this is partly due to governance (fear driven) and also the lack of experienced staff.  

A lot of good staff have left over the last few years and the clean brooms at the top level do not have the corporate knowledge to implement their ideas. 

There have been a number of new ways of working, operating models and structures, each time the person who brings this new idea then leaves the organisation before the model gets a chance to become embedded.

The increasing movement of jobs from the UK to India in order to cut costs has resulted in a number of third party companies in the sub-continent making a lot of money from the Bank. Within technology the net effect has been lowering of morale in onshore staff, lower quality and increased timescales.

The organisation is now very much smaller but in some areas the workload has increased, with redundancies and attrition there is now a real shortage of managers in some areas. The remaining managers have too large a workload to do their job effectively and the stress is palpable.

Political interference has been extremely damaging to the Bank. In particular the EU requirement to divest a part of the UK business. This has swallowed up people and money and has prevented the Bank investing in its technology to serve the organisation and its customers.

Good learning and training opportunities
Lots of focus on improvements currently
cons:
Slow salary growth and progress
can be very bureaucratic

headline: Great experience and Training
pros: Good atmosphere and team work
cons: Not very easy for career progression

headline: I find my role challenging but rewarding.
pros: We are given a clear direction of what we are trying to achieve as a bank and this allows us to set personal goals. We also get perks such as flexible contracts i.e. if we work a Saturday we can have the time off in the working week. this gives us a good work life balance.
cons: I am happy to take on extra responsibilities but would like recognition because it certainly isn't reflected in my salary. Also no benefits come with being an employee e.g. they used to offer staff accounts etc. if such benefits do exsist I have not been made aware.

headline: Must try harder with customers
pros:
Good People
Decent working environment
Flexible arrangements if required
cons: Not enough customer focus (despite our "values")

headline: Very educational experience
pros: Although not the most glorious place to work at the moment, this place actually taught me more than I expect. Training program is exceptional and steep learning curve.
cons: Not much monetary advancement prospect in the long haul.

headline: One sentence is never enough to describe one of the best work experiences I have ever heard. SUPERB!
pros: Equality, team building activities, human understanding, pay, training.
cons: It kind of makes one bummed out to not be able to express their true feelings without fear of ridicule or expulsion.

headline: Nice place to start, bad place to stay.
pros:
* stability of employment (as currently company can't level its salary levels to competitors - pressure is lowered)
* flexible working scheme (you come to work from 6 to 11 [in some teams others have 8-10] and work 8 hours)
* multiple working schedules to fit your needs
* even if you're green in terms of banking with the time you'll get some knowledge
* benefits (multisport, lunchpass, medical care, life policy and sometimes company shares)
* corporate race in most team kept at reasonable level (not too low, not too high)
* in Ops Dpt. - good work-life balance in most teams
* in Ops Dpt - usually 8hrs job - do what you have then go home
cons:
* salary - after you pay the rent, bills, travel card and grocery - the amount left sometimes makes you cry
* office politics everywhere involving backstabbing and idea stealing
* nepotism outside Ops. Dpt. - as someone in company said : "Once in operations, forever in operations"
* very difficult to get outside Operations if you don't have necessary contacts
* routine
* bad pay/effort ratio - you get same salary for doing really complicated process or for simple data entry
* unnecessary meetings, not intended to bring anything of value, bad rather handclappinf because we've met target
* some processes are not straight 8hrs jobs
* really low chances to get a promotion - it's not achievable through hard work but rather by being team leader's pet
* managers who don't know how to do they job, and sometimes can't even speak proper English
* unprofessionalism of some people, as outstanding percent of employes are students

headline: Ok place to work
pros: free food, good work life balance.
cons: Lot of bureaucracy,  .

headline: Not very good work culture, do not promote the talent,  have no vision
pros: Just one - good work life balance
cons: Do not promote talent focus mainly on non work aspects, clueless top management, no vision, too much focus on cost

headline: check my market value
pros: facilities in RBs are outstanding
cons: not satisfied with the company process

headline: Days in RBS
pros: Good Facilities - cafeteria, work area, gym free cabs etc
cons: Like any other captives RBS has an issue with the middle management and vendor population, In some areas Vendors are diluting the work culture.

headline: Financial Analyst
pros: Good atmosphere and people to work with
cons: job security, and low compensation when compared to other top banks

headline: Above Average
pros:
Good hike when joining
If in right project, decent amount of learning.
Excellent Benefits - 30 Days Annual Leave, Free Cab Services, Free Lunch & Snacks, Good Benefits Plan that helps you save on Income Tax
Lots of resources to learn.
Work/Life Balance.
cons:
Promotions are a challenge.
Visible Politics
No Onsite at all - If you extremely lucky, you get to travel to UK for a week or two
Gurgaon has more training programs, projects, etc than Chennai.
Life gets monotonous after a while, not a lot of projects that you can move to..

headline: Experiance
pros:
1. Good and latest Technologies if you are in M&IB.
2. Work Life Balance is good for Manager Level People in m&IB but for developers they will think they are labors.
3. Leave policy
4. No Variable Pay
5. M&IB good hikes 
6. Transport, Insurance cover(5 times of pkg).
cons:
You have to be very communicative in the team otherwise you don't no what is happening.
No traings, No functional or Technical KTs

headline: Competitive, collaborative and great place to work
pros: Good work life balance, reasonable comp relaxed work atmosphere
cons: Big company is very slow to respond to anything. Getting even small stuff done is very hard.

headline: equity derivatives sales
pros:
good working hours
1h30 lunch breaks
8 to 18 (sales)
good vacations
cons:
total lack of direction
middle management has no idea where business is going

headline: Used to be the best bank to work for, now the worst.  The rot started with the ABN Amro purchase and continued,
pros: Investment banking - still an excellent industry to be in.  Still the leading bank in FX, although undermined by several scandals recently.
cons: Run by egomaniacs and as personal fiefdoms.  People hired for the wrong reasons, politics out of control. Control functions disproportionately powerful, too many business prevention officers.  Leadership full of hot air, talk the talk - which always turns out to be BS.

headline: Satisfied
author_position: Regional Human Resources MIS and Technical Analyst
pros: Challenging Environment...had a wonderful collegue team and seniors to work with
cons: Work life balance could be imprioved

headline: Nice environment, inefficient leadership
pros: - Smart and friendly co-workers. Laid-back atmosphere compared to other competitors in the industry which contributes to decent work-life balance. Some opportunity for independence.
cons:
-This place isn't suitable for ambitious person - absence of environment that fosters progress and advancement, as they would most likely satisfy on status quo.
- Rigid organisation makes promotion a rare thing. Too much middle-management practically contributing nothing to  company.

headline: Demoralising
pros: Has recently made the effort to recognise and retain talented staff.
cons: Demoralising when everyone around you is being fired. The office culture is fairly stuffy with no social interaction.

headline: Good pay but no Growth
pros:
Leave Policy is Good
Good transportation
cons:
No trainings
Too many conditional approvals for Work from home
Need to fill Return to Work form for even a single sickness leave (Suspecting nature)
No good cafeteria
lack of leadership

headline: Banking Industry
pros:
Brand & Work Atmosphere
Company Value
cons:
Management Constrains
Growth & Future Career

headline: US presence is in shrink mode
pros: Many of the people in Stamford are very competent and diligent,  There is very good Interactions between departments and you can learn new ideas from each area.  Stamford has state of the art technology. Work-life balance is very good.  There will be long days, but the trade off is management will allow you to work at home every now and then.
cons: As of now the bank in the US overall is still shrinking, so an increase in compensation won't happen for most people.   Unfortunately this is the same for career opportunities.  Its not clear what plans Senior Management has for the US besides trying to IPO their largest US subsidiary, Citizensbank, and the reduction of personnel on the investment bank side.  RBS is 84% owned by the UK Taxpayers, so UK management listens very closely to what the government wants the bank to do.  In turn UK management tells the US management what the strategy of the day, month or year will be.

headline: Good company to work with
pros:
Good work life balance
Good exposure BFSI domain projects
cons: None which I can mention

headline: Good experience
pros: Great work life balance, good compensation, free meals and cab facility
cons: Lot of focus on vendors and out sourcing. This limits the learning path of RBS employees. Dont expect to become a technology expert in RBS. Too many and too complicated processes.

headline: Good Experience with my company
pros:
Balanced Work life
Opportunities were plenty 
Training was good
Management were friendly
Supporting funds for charity
cons:
Increment was too low
HR policies frequently changing
Good package for the freshers
Inside Politics
Experienced people are not retained

headline: Fantastic
pros: RBS working enviroment is awesome
cons: Growth is stagnant and limited

headline: Excellent work life balance
pros: Management encourages  work life balance
cons: Extremely limited opportunity for growth and almost no promotions in technology division.

headline: Has it's ups and down, but over all a good place to work
pros: Great work / life balance. From day one I had 20 days of PTO to use each year, plus all the banking holidays. A great starting wage. The company has a strong focus on volunteer work, which is good to give back
cons: The banking industry is still going through a recovering faze after the '08 crash. RBS is majority owned by the UK government, and the raising level of auditors and regulators is staggering. Morale is low, as positions are being taken back east, or to India.

headline: OK
pros: Work life balance and Benefits(earlier , now declining)
cons: Worst compensation, Appraisals, Declining benefits

headline: Dead end job
pros: I was there almost 3 years and was given lots of responsibility which was good and made me fees important. The people working there are great and made it all the better.
cons: They got us to do lots of extra work outside of my job title without paying any extra. There was nowhere to go.. they laid off lots of people above me so I was just stuck doing what I was doing. Even if I had got promoted, I probably would have been made redundant! Also the bonus is capped so no matter how hard you work, its always the same amount you will receive.

headline: Operations Analyst
pros: Good culture.. People are willing to help you out. Reasonable hours.
cons: Compesnsation. Location is not in New York City. The firm's reputation in Europe is not good at all and not too much better in the US.

headline: Good working environment, overly controlling boss
pros: good benefits (but salary was low). had a lot of training which could be done if you wanted to. nice staff and colleagues, we used to get each other coffee from the cheap canteen. fair holidays
cons: low salary. line manager was a little controlling and took a little too much interest in what was going on.  nothing was that bad though.

headline: Great work-life balance!
pros:
Work life balance
salary
perks like free food, free transportation, excellent insurance
cons: Lack of clarity in vision from higher management

headline: Pathetic
pros: Exposure in Indian Operations, Apart from this I could not find anything better at RBS.
cons: Policies, verbal policies. Employees have to fight for their salary increment which is due for not less than 10 months.

headline: A rollercoaster
pros: Getting time during my awful training session to apply for jobs
cons: Personal growth has been diminished with underpayment and redundancy

headline: Caveat emptor
pros: On the whole nice people, not too many egos, good work life balance,30 days holiday, lots of volunteering opportunities.
cons:
Poor management confused at where the bank is going, not surprisingly due to Govt interference.
Terrible compensation- staff with no pay rises or bonuses for > 5yrs. Few promotion prospects, lots of Offshoring. Low morale, with many people just waiting for pay outs.

headline: Good people, bad bank due to historical reasons, India management top-notch.
pros:
- Lots of new opportunities coming to Gurgaon Technology office, supported by pressure on bank's costs.
- Objective reviews, great people in India.
- Interim out-of-turn hikes for top performers.
- Good focus on trainings
- One of the very few Investment Banks that follow the local office hours
- More structured than other I-Banks (I have worked with 4 other different IBs in India)
cons:
- Salaries falling behind the curve causing exodus of top talent.
- Junior to middle management in London just trying to save their jobs.
- Management structure changes too often as pressure of undoing all the wrongs too high
- Extremely high public scrutiny in the UK media

headline: Haven't got rid of the old wood
pros: good benefits, nice people, work from home
cons: Bad behaviours are not called, peoples own agenda not what is best for RBS, bonus round is really important for most people even though they are bankrupt ( UK govt had to barrel them out). A culture of keeping people in their boxes - worked in HR and painful lengths of process and their is no team work - old school HR I think the average service of the HR exec is 18yrs need new blood with lean thinking.

headline: Wonderful place to work
pros: The company invests a lot in employees' development and training. Managers are great - friendly and helpful, real experts in their area, leading others by their own example.
cons: Haven't found anything negative. Brilliant experience all in all, great colleagues and wonderful place to work.

headline: Business banking - good experience but not in the long run
pros:
- friendly atmosphere
-  work 9 to 5
- all the training provided
cons:
-  low salary increased by time you served not so much by merit
-  very limited opportunities for promotion

headline: Good Work Life Balance, but limited prospects.
pros:
Good Work Life Balance, flexible benefits package
Flexible time/working hours (come in early, go home early)
Great people to work with.
Relaxed environment and as long as you get your work done, no officious-ness
cons:
Low base salary, topped up by "flexible benefits package".
"Dead-man's shoes" - Have to wait until someone dies to get promoted.
Not great career progression
Too many systems/processes that are unclear and inefficient.

headline: Good company
pros: Good communication and the company has great training.
cons: The lack of variety in a role and no opportunity to progress that high up. Overtime is always encouraged but the hours don't always seem to be recorded accurately.

headline: Good work/life balance, but lots of egos
pros: Some smart people still, good work/life balance
cons: Bureaucracy, Depressing environment, egos, feeling of a downward trajectory

headline: Just started working in RBS
pros:
Work Life Balance 
Cab facility 
Food 
Leaves
cons: Yet to identify as recently joined so honeymoon period going on

headline: mixed- it all depends on the department and the manager
pros: many opportunities if you make yourself available
cons:
poor management- no clear vision from top down
lack of communication across business units or departments or regions
lack of respect or understanding for other cultures
lack of diversity at management level (women, etc)
old boys club all the way

headline: 6 months in RBS
pros: The only valid reason is Salary increment (for those who are less paid initially in their jobs), and a good brand name (at least the market have that impression)
cons: No work life balance; limited growth opportunity, too many levels of hierarchy. The bonus and hikes are minimal and on the lower side of the industry average

headline: RBS as a Company
pros: Great Company to learn things, work life balance, lot of facilities
cons: RBS as a business not doing great, lot of restructuring

headline: Good work life balance
pros: Office timings,Work culture,Policies are Good
cons: Slow Growth, Promotion are very rare,

headline: Former employee
pros:
People at RBS are simply great. Intelligent, hard working with the drive to get ahead.
Good starting salary.
cons:
Not a single project gets completed because of politics.
Management strategy changes every other day.
No career progression
No pay rise
No bonus
No promotion.
HR is useless.

headline: Diversity champion
pros: The bank has a warm environment, which champions diversity. Whether that be your ethnicity or sexuality or a multitude of other qualities. My personal experience found that the work hours were very flexible which suited me as I was a student at the time.
cons: I enjoy a varied workload which challenges me and stretches my capability. I found my role grew very monotonous.

headline: Good life work balance
pros:
1 hour lunch break
9 to 5
cons:
low salary
too much restructuring taking place

headline: Poor management, but generally a pleasant place to work
pros: Reasonable pay and a more balanced culture post recession. Generally, nice people to work with. Reasonable facilities. Could be worse.
cons: Weak management, inappropriate pressures from government lead to poor commercial decisions. A very large operation of several businesses, still somewhat bureaucratic.

headline: "Good to Great" was on old slogan.  The reality is "great to horrendous".
pros: In the past we worked hard for our customers, there was great teamworking and we were rewarded fairly well.  Recently the only good points for me were being paid, working within walking distance from home and school.
cons: Hardly anyone left with banking or technology/system experience.  The managers don't care about their staff or working environment, they only work out what they need to do to get the biggest pay rise or promotion.  The majority definitely don't care about customers.  They rely on poorly paid staff in India who are stressed out and haven't a clue what they are doing.   I worked there for 24 years and only in the last 2 did I come across bullying, blackmail, no trust, people lying.

headline: ok
pros: thr wlb is good enough
cons: role clarity is not there

headline: Kept me in a job for 2 years but was 2 years of uncertainty.
pros: You meet loads of people working for them, and the pay is not so bad considering similar roles, can be an easy going job depending on the role.
cons: The hours can be a challenge due to shift patterns, weekend work becoming increasingly mandatory along with bank holidays, annual holiday is very hard to get agreed due to huge volumes of staff (in call centres), too many managers without skill to actually manage. No room to exceed and when there is staff are usually hand picked and not given an opportunity. There is a huge lack of overtime availability (none for almost 9 months solid). More than 6 people have already left my department.

headline: It's my second family and has been with me through thick and thin for 30 years! Only family do that.
pros:
Senior staff have finally adapted a joined up approach to have all areas of business working together as one team.  Ie branch business and private teams. This will definitely help to deliver an excellent service to our customers.
Flexible working hours to provide a good work home balance. Happy staff at home will lead to happy staff at work delivering excellent service with passion.
cons: I found it very demotivating at end of a great year to be told although you have had a great year the bank are not giving level 5 this year. After 4 years at level 5 consistently,it left me demotivated to start a new year of business.

headline: memorable and with good team managers
pros: the location is very good as there are a lot of sociable places nearby. It is also very nice to work in the same building as many differently skilled people. One can build connections and good rapport with more senior colleagues to better understand the organisation
cons: strictly financial and customer service which can be monotonous

headline: Good Place but uncertain future
pros:
Infrastructure - when one walks into the Gurgaon office will feel like they have entered a true MNC.
Work Culture  - Friendly culture over all except for few teams 
Learning         - If you have it in you to learn new domain no.one will stop you even if you are stranger to the domain. But expectations on deliverables are high.
Transport   - Both ways AC cabs
Food.          - Best food realy delicious and hygienic nothing less than a 3-4 sr stndrd
cons:
Uncertainty - Because of year on year losses there is sence of uncertainty.
Policies       - Nothing is black n white
Growth.       - Growth is very much specific to the team
HR.              - No role of HR apart.from hiring

headline: The people are doing their best but the company is a zombie.
pros: The retail bank is definitely headed in the right direction and for years has been headed by well intended senior managers.  NatWest is still a strong brand and many Customers are very loyal.
cons: The culture just can't seem to move forward.  The meddling from the government means that the bank is over capitalised but that leaves it without any ability to lend.  There is constant cost cutting and the technology is ancient.

headline: Power-hungry, racist, sexist psychopaths
pros: Big company, well structured benefits scheme, lots of training, the company will invest in you if you're in the right position, but don't expect to get treated well if you're in a call centre, customer service, branch etc.
cons: Encountered sexism from senior women and racism from senior men.  I got told by a senior manager to shave my beard because "I look like a terrorist" and by my supervisor that "I am useless because I'm a man" despite doing triple the workload of my peers.

headline: Often draining, sometimes rewarding.
pros: Supportive environment from direct line management. Apparently good financial product offers.
cons: Large focus on one area such as productivity, then when that affects quality of work, a focus on that, then they wonder why productivity slips. Unrealistic targets set by upper management who have no idea how to do the specific job.

headline: A place that will groom you adapt to changes and recognise staff contribution.
pros: People centric, good company values and office culture
cons: managing through organisational changes could be challenging for staff who is inexperienced in adopting and delivering during organisational restructuring.

headline: The people are great immediate line management is good, but the people at the top still make bad decisions.
author_position: Several Starting As A CSA Ended As DCH
pros: pay is ok and the value account benefit tops up your salary considerably, the people are great and no one parties like RBS staff
cons: goal posts constantly moving if you find it difficult to meet targets

headline: The Royal Bank of Scotland
pros:
Significant refocus on customers, their needs and serving them well. Outstanding and valuable brands to be associated with as a member of staff.

Outstanding commitment to the environment, being a leader in lending for renewable energy and substantial community engagement opportunities for staff to be part of.
cons: None really - some staff are unhappy with compensation levels but ultimately it was important to show restraint in pay.

headline: Senior Product Manager
pros: Changing culture, new management , too many managers
cons: No Structure, legacy culture, slow change

headline: Uncertainty at current time
pros:
Reasonable work life balance depending on role and team lead
a few bad apples now and then but generally office culture among peers is friendly
Training mainly learn on job or self directed so you can learn at your own pace
cons:
Not much to look forward to in terms of career progression, limited opportunities unless replacement role
Company is trying to turn around, therefore is creating more uncertainty among rank and files
Seems to be ahead of competition in terms of achieving its right size, how many more years, no one knows

headline: Technical Lead PeopleSoft
pros: Work life balance. Complex technical infrastructure helps to gain understanding on the technology in the best possible way.
cons: Lack of clarity on future growth and road map.No advancement in career path.

headline: Vice President
pros: Driven by Government, customer focus
cons: The bank is restructuring and hence potential job losses. The environment is not condusive to growth.

headline: Good working culture and nice enviornment
pros: Simple and steady job, Has very less work pressure
cons: Growth  is very slow in this organisation

headline: good to work
pros:
good salary 
good work culture
No much work.good work life balance.
Good transport facility.
Food is very good
cons: Did get much time to work over there to see any issue.

headline: Great work place
pros: Great and detailed training. Customer focused organisation.
cons:
The management has to retain the talent and circulate them with in the organisation  .They are good in retaining the employees but the role changes are really slow and in the same stream .

The pay is a bit less than the market but one who is in for a new carrier that is no other company who can beat the training

headline: Capital Markets Summer Internship
pros: Nice people, good working environment
cons: Face time seemed to be the most important thing, not rewarding good work

headline: Excellent work life balance
pros: Offers excellent work life balance, well respected
cons: The internal department structure , not very lucrative year end increment  and bonus

headline: I would stay away from this company
pros: Stamford office is state of the art and the staff is very friendly.
cons: Commute, Poorly managed areas and senior management constantly change gears...hard to see the direction of the company because of this.

headline: Team Lead
pros:
Employee friendly organization
Work life balance
Good Culture
Benefits
Work is challenging.
cons:
Technologies used are stale.
Too much politics

headline: Business Analyst review
pros: Given a lot of responsibility  from day 1
cons: Has a very stressful working environment

headline: Decent pay with good people to work with depending on the department
pros: If you work hard, people will notice you and give you more responsibility to grow your career.  Based pay are at market and great PTO policy.   It is very hard to find another place with better PTO policy.
cons: Bonus is limited by British Government (bad business combination when you are controlled by government).   No communication between departments.  Work in Solo.  No horizontal movement to other department after reaching VP level.

headline: Good place to work
pros: You should work here..if you want a peaceful life. you can spent time with your family,friends. this company will give you a full work life balance.
cons: once you join this company as a technical IT guy your growth will be stopped in organisation because this company is not a IT company its a bank.

headline: RBS employees are least paid as per market standard.
pros: You get to work very jolly, friendly and good set of people who would make you feel at home in office too. Work culture is slightly better. Food.
cons: First thing is salary - Avg package 2.27 lakh(House maid salary ), They are on the verge of implementing only drops and no pickups in transport. Too many system incidents leads to surge of workload. Work life balance is pathetic for some departments. Too much politics in appraisal and no proper reward and recognition for hard workers. No growth plans for employees except rare management pets and no retention policy.

headline: Great Work Life Balance
pros:
Work life balance
Cab facility
Office timings 8am-5pm
cons: Job Security, No promotions, Line Managers rule.

headline: Very Lethargic and political org
pros: If you want a paid holiday
cons: Slow pace of work, Favoritism, No Learning opportunities

headline: Employee Friendly
pros: Work Life Balance, Job Security
cons: Promotions not given as per the timelines, eventhough employee performance has exceeded the SMART's.

headline: Not the perfect place to work for
pros: You are given some freedom
cons: The managers do whatever they want do, and they sweet talk you, but will never protect you..they will do illegal stuff, but will clip you if you do it because it benefits them

headline: Good work life balance
pros:
Work life Balance
Stable
Culture depends on Team you are working
cons: Career opportunities or promotions are less

headline: Good Work Life Balance..
pros: good culture with real people value..though still in crisis moving strongly in the right path
cons: org structure is like a noodles, this makes difficult for people to get noticed and on the other hand makes it even tougher for effective management

headline: Truely "ROYAL" in real sense!!
pros:
One definately realises the best after leaving RBS :)
I was always proud of and I am still proud to be associated with this great organisation.

1) People centric. They really treat you like a human being rather than just bodies with a suitable mind to binge on which most companies are nowadays.
2) Every individual is treated with respect. This is what I like the most. Even the contracters are managed with great respect (although some of the contracters given to us are really DUMB but nobody used to yell at them... that's the culture which makes it royal and not some local bodyshop)
3) Quality of work is good but since project delays are common so execution takes time which takes away the real essence.
4) PAY is decent 
5) The best part - FOOD is AWESOME !!!! Yummy... hygienic....
6) Transportation is another very strong selling point since very few companies really bother to provide decent transportation ....
cons:
1) Some managers are from poor service companies and they are not absorbing the real culture/values of the company.. they cant digest people leaving at 5 so they will always be looking for some stupid reasons to make you stay longer.... these FOOLS are not realizing that this will take them nowhere....You really have to be the part of a company to grow with it....
2) I never understood the criteria of bonus distribution... although it gives an impression that it is given to people closer to the immediate manager....
3) Hikes are really bad for average performers... only 20% employees are above average..So if you are in that 20 it will be really good else you will have to look outside after a couple of years for your own appaisal :)

headline: Inefficient and bureaucratic company
pros: Agile working has been a massive plus point of working at RBS with the ability to work at home 2-3 days a week. However, this does vary by department is is still frowned upon by many Senior Management so although they promote agile working in practise, many are in the office 4-5 days a week. Benefits are very good with self-select on a number of options such as pension, private healthcare.
cons: Currently going through massive re-structure with large amount of roles going in back office and frontline sales increasing. New CEO and new structure with same old people leading. Company talk about employee engagement yet morale is low. Employee Opinion Survey is undertaken once a year and yet with incredibly poor scores for my area I haven't seen one action to help improve what people said, clearly a tick in the box exercise. Very inefficient with big blame culture, copying loads of people in unnecessarily on emails, bullies and too many old timers who have been there 20-30 years and are set in their ways. There are some great people in the company but many lack ownership and empowerment, also some of the worst people I have ever worked with, horrible. If you are in marketing, projects are handed off to a Marketing Delivery team for fulfilment who often take ages to get things done. Really bureaucratic processes and backward systems. Risk adverse and big fear factor in many areas. Never seen so many meetings, people in meetings, working groups and numbers on conference calls. Lots of silo's and changes in strategy common.

headline: Good place to learn banking and IT together
pros:
1- Good salary
2- Open environment
3- Options to learn and work what you want.
cons: 1- Slowly the people with fake exprience and knowledge level are getting hold.

headline: RBS India
pros: RBS is nice company to work with. It has employee friendly environment in place to groom them for higher level. Thats the reason i found many people having more than 5+ years of experience. It provides execllent business and technincal exposure to gain.
cons: During my tenure i found out that RBS india was not that aggressive in enough to grab the work and making it as a profit centre (which most ot the companies in similar line of business were eying upon). Thus leading to major job cut here in india as well.

headline: Best Work Life Balance
pros:
Has to be the best work life balance in this company
Salary structure is good..
cons: No on sight opportunities in my office

headline: Good Work life balance, low pressure but almost zero growth opportunities
pros: Transport Facility, Low work pressure, Good Work Life balance and lots of leaves
cons:
Rest Everything is pathetic!
1. Compensation is much below the Industry Standards
2. Your Manager decides your future (Always say Yes Boss, then only expect something good)
3. In case you resign, you are treated as a step son (all your privileges are withdrawn, even your yearly bonus, which itself is worthless figure)
4. 360 degree review is discouraged
5. Personal growth is almost nil (Expect a promotion at least after 5-6 years)
6. Management least concerned about employees issues/grievances.

headline: Good work life balance thats it
pros:
After spending a large amount of time, one tends to get cynical with an organization, so let me try and put up and impartial view of the org. Main pros

1) work life balance: 8-5 working hours mean 8-5 thats it.
2) cab facility :- free cab service in NCR
3) decent salary structure.
cons:
Ok this is the dicey part being an old timer I might be cynical and give bitter views so I will try to be rational and balanced.

Cons

1) being a captive of a stagnant business, there is absolutely no growth over here.
2) internal promotions are non existent. A policy called IJP which involves an interview(just like for an external candidate). If you are chummy with the Sr management this IJP will be as easy as a kindergarden interview else the complexity can even surpass IAS UPSC interview.
3) absolutely no onsite . Only onsite would be to Chennai/Gurgaon that too requiring approval upto Division/ country head and what not.
4) huge salary disparity - very much possible that a manager earning less than his subordinate

headline: customer oriented
pros: employee oriented, customer oriented, good working culture
cons: i had always a great experience

headline: Could have been better.
pros: The recruitment process was not strenuous and  you had a feeling that they genuinely wanted you there. You get exposed to a  whole gamut of financial products and services. The buzz around the office was great and colleagues were never too busy to help if you needed pointers. The system was undergoing a transition when I got in-following the GFC- and  a lot of the processes were being modified, especially in relation to company values and opportunities for personal growth.
cons: The induction training was wholly inadequate and unrealistic. Quite a lot of the day to day challenges were not adequately captured by the training and some aspects were, frankly, without relevance to your job role and seemingly over-emphasized. Also staff seemed  very tense and under tremendous pressure to deliver.

headline: Struggling to manage change
pros: Located in the heart of The City and populated with some very bright, ambitious and driven people, they have a culture that rewards those who are able to grasp their responsibilities, own those and then are ambitious in taking on new ones. Those who have a clear understanding of their responsibilities and consistently deliver quality product are very well regarded. Management will invest in people who demonstrate an ambition allied with a well considered career path,
cons: Given the extent of change due to the ABN takeover, the changing regulatory landscape, the change in the nature of the market, etc. there is an element of "change fatigue" that might have crept in. Leadership have also been somewhat remiss in clearly defining a strategy that capitalises on the changing industry outlook and have consistently failed to invest in IT systems.

headline: Great Work Life Balance, But too Much Focus on Company change, not enough employee retention
pros:
Utah office - fantastic work life balance, great hours. 
Salary is competitive based on experience
Great people to work with
cons:
There are way too many company initiatives employees are expected to be on board with (without adequate reward). Initiatives are a blatant cost/headcount reduction exercises.
Not enough employee recognition, development and reward

headline: Good

wholesale were out of kilter with what he is trying to achieve.
He is likely to cut middle-management layers, however, and unveil a major investment in technology to help the bank regain the confidence of its customers following a series of techn

headline: Best Pace to Work

headline: Poor culture letting it down
pros: Scale! Access to good resources and development.  Fantastic HQ building with good flexible working policies.  Has potential for good internal career development once you are in the door.  Good overall compensation.
cons: High blame culture, politics at Senior Manager level.  Paying lip service to employee engagement.  The silo mentality means its difficult to get things done.

headline: Making the best of a bad situation
pros:
1.  The people are generally quite friendly.
2.  Management makes an effort to keep staff informed of new business strategies and developments.
3.  Bank has a commitment to diversity and respect for others.
cons:
1.  After 5-6 years of losses, layoffs, a constant stream of bad press, and being forced to "do more with less", the staff are demoralized and exhausted - and looking for other opportunities elsewhere.
2.  Business strategy keeps changing and nothing ever seems to work.
3.  Compensation levels (especially bonuses) are far below those of its competitors.
4.  Organization is too bureacratic and unwieldy.
5.  Too many policies and procedures to keep track of and comply with.
6.  Too many computer tools and applications to keep track of and learn how to use.
7.  Perks and benefits are below par (e.g., the company match on the 401-K doesn't kick in until after one full year of employment).
8.  Bank is more reactive than proactive and always seems to be in damage-control mode.

headline: HR BP
pros: People - respectful working environment
cons: company on a downward trend since recession

headline: No Job Security, Stressful work environment
pros: Shift Timings are good, Leaves are good

headline: Generally a good company to work for
pros: Good people, my colleagues are fantastic. Work Like balance is good. Introduction of more  customer focussed approach in a Conduct Risk environment, striving to thinking long terms and 'doing the right thing'.
cons: Disjointed strategy within different departments and salary and reward packages low in comparison to main competitors. Not much willingness for anything 'outside the box' in terms of pay. Negative media coverage often brings moral down.

headline: Change and more change.
pros: There's a lot of work to be done to put the business back on track, so there are plenty of opportunities for personal growth/development. Leadership is strong in certain areas.
cons: Lots of uncertainty for the future of the business. Press indicates significant downsizing is possible. Has been subject of negative press for the last 5 years and will no doubt be the subject of negative press for years to come. Hard company to be proud of working for.

headline: Lacking direction and commitment
