cons:
Business is conducted to the letter and not always to the spirit.
Thinking and ways of working is stuck in the past.
Bulk of staff appear to treat environment as just as a 9-5 job and just accept things as they are.
Repeatedly having to watch bad press reports on failings which really should not have happened.

headline: Only for the Netherlands branch of RBS
pros: The company has a good social plan therefore the conditions are very good. Its pension is young, meaning there are more contributors than pensioners, thus its has a positive cash flow. They are very conservative on what they invest in. The pension was fully paid when I joined, but that might have changed.
cons: Unclear if they are going to stay in the Netherlands. A lot of the hub departments that are based in NL were inherited from the takeover of ABN AMRO and they have been busy for the last 5 3 years in reducing it as much as possible. There are certain business lines that are being closed. The future for RBS in NL is to be only a branch, so in my view there will not be that much back office work here.

cons:

headline: Bitter after taste
pros: There are very few pros when it comes to working at RBS. I will admit to having a lot of good times there prior to the last couple of years that I was there. It was an easy commute into Edinburgh and the working hours were convenient.
cons:
In my last couple of years there the atmosphere changed for the worse and it was obvious that the aim of the organisation was reduce headcount to leave only the best performing staff to run the ship. I respected that approach, but there was too much pressure put on those who were deemed to be under-performing. I came into that category, but I strongly believed that I was being unfairly marked down. I was a hard working and loyal member of staff who always enjoyed a challenge, but because management didn't give me enough time for vital training, I struggled to do the job I was being asked to do. The Union was involved in my case, and they agreed with me, but I was left with no option but to apply for voluntary. This was accepted, but I'm still left with a bitter after-taste. 
Don't join RBS if you want a stress-free job. If you are one of the absolute best, you will be fine, but if you are anything other than that, you will not stand a chance.

headline: Excellent US operation hampered by financially troubled parent

headline: Internal Audit with 2 years of experience

headline: Smoke and Mirrors, shifting sands, high churn and confused messaging.
pros:
Great work-life balance, you truly are the master of your own working life
Genuine push for change in values and desire to build a better bank
There are some good people who have clawed their way up against all odds
Open culture, no bad feeling if the job isn't for you. People generally get along and the feeling in the building is generally quite positive. 
Not as much internal/ team level politics as with many other firms. 
Excellent benefits proposition, flex working welcomed, generous holiday allowance.
cons:
Bully-boy tactics by senior leaders to get their way; very much still cult of personality as you get to the top of the hierarchy- tantrumming execs usually get their way. 
Every few months the strategy changes; new buzzwords, new structures, new rules to live your life by... 
Unless you are under the wing of somebody senior your career will stagnate and die. The best thing you can do is join high, stay for a year or two and then move on.
Horrible ancient systems that  don't communicate with each other and frequently crash and leak. 
"Ivory tower" - in HR the leaders sit in Edinburgh and the little worker ants are based in London. They have no clue what anybody does, many times during meetings they're asking to review projects that finished months ago. 
Promises re; development and progression that never materialise. 
Too much dead wood; here since they were 16, close to retiring and basically coasting because they know it's too expensive to fire them.

The very best earned promotions, the average kept their jobs, the worst got removed- just the way it should be. Outstanding benefits even compared to peer group.

cons: no room for growth and seniority matters. So suggestions go unheard. Some managers and seniors are too proud to listen to others. Some managers probably should never been managers and find excuses to avoid work; company also finds excuse to avoid bonus payout. Lack of recognition or awards.

cons: There is no Cons for this company that I can think of as it was the best place for me. So all i can say that cons is a term that i cannot seem to associate with this company.

headline: Senior management of poor quality
pros: Good working colleagues who have managed to survive all the terrible waves of redundancy and nice office location. And by working, I meant those real people who are working and not directors who put on a false front.
cons: Stability is an issue - head counts kept reducing even after people quit. Directors are made up of incapable people who were promoted or given wonderful titles that has always puzzled all. With directors that are more worried about keeping their own jobs, you will see the analyst or associates or VP working their arse off without due recognition.

headline: Great starting point...turned sour quickly
pros: The benefit entitlements for contract roles were the best I ever had. They take care of their employees in that sense, it makes the job more enticing. Some nice people to work with too.
cons: Innovation is slow and the excuse you keep getting is "compliance" issues. If you want to be the innovative bank, make it easy for creativity to thrive. Don't kill the creativity.

Few people really have your back regardless of how much value you added.

headline: Mixed

headline: Transparency will be more appreciated.
pros:
If you enjoy minimal supervision and am a self-starter, this is an awesome working place to be at. 
You will learn new things on self-discovery on a daily basis as you go through your workflow processes. 
If you are a fast learner, its a 9-5 job by the 3rd month after climbing the steep learning curve.
A good testing point to know where your product knowledge is at within the financial industry.
Meeting people who have hopped around banks
cons:
Due to the flat structure in departments, tendency to promote the wrong people happens frequently resulting to some managers/team leads that are too busy covering their own bottoms or taking credit for work done by others are so frequent if you encounter horrible ones which positively viewed is mentioned in the pros and when a rare occasion of a good line manager comes along it is quickly sweep and taken in to other departments managed by more senior management personnel. 

Management are secretive about their plans for the departments. For eg, Shutting down of another department where employees are given only a weeks notice that the plan will be commencing.

The designations generally map with more years of experience as compared to industry.

headline: Dont see myself pursuing a career at this particular bank
pros: Good opportunity for experience decent salary, quite fair with flexi
cons: Very unorganised as a new entrant wasnt given much guidance. On first day was told to answer the phones and if i didn't know the answer take a message and then left to it(seeing as ive no previous experience i wouldnt know answers to most questions) still unsure of some procedures today find myself very uncomfortable when going off to ask questions whilst serving customers and having no one to actually ask. Have been told recently that ive been here long enough (a few months) to know certain procedures that ive never done and nobody has shown me. So many things which i come across regularlybut have never been sat down with someone running throughit step by step. I get that people are busy lots to do but i think they should have a plan of action for new entrants before accepting them so that less mistakes are made. They have told me everyonemakes mistakes but i dont see it like that when its other peoples money im dealing with. Weve been told that we dont have targets to meet yet it is very high pressured when it comes to booking appts etc. I get businesses need sales but i find it disheartening if the business cannot be honest with its staff about targets and what happens if you dont meet them.

headline: An honest and unbiased review of working at RBS in Singapore (Back-end role)
pros:
- Good team culture, open culture, people work together to solve problems, daily 15 min huddles are conducted daily gives people an opportunity to highlight problems faced.
- Surveys are often conducted to measure the performances of managers, existing workload. In order words feed back is conducted, and they try to resolve it.
- Nice colleagues. 
- Opportunities to work overseas in London.
- Opportunities are available for internal transfer if you are able to network within the department. (very easy as there are outings, drinks night held often interactions with other team heads is easy)
cons:
- Cost cutting bank, hence do not expect increments at the end of the year. Your best bet is to negotiate for a higher salary when you first join. (hope this helps)
- for bonuses, you need a rating of at least 4/5 to be considered. Hence most people don't get it.
- No job security even if you are a permanent staff, operations are continuously being outsourced overseas.
- Head count not being replaced, (perm staff leaves, a contract head count is given), 
- People are consistently leaving, making handovers very rushed and done improperly. 
- Hard to achieve work life balance, as the teams are already under-staff, expect to do more than one person's workload. Most are expected to 'double up'
- System wise, quite outdated, but I can say that, in 2013, they have started upgrading aspects of their systems.

headline: good

Pros: 

Employee facilities like Cab, Food  are excellent. 
RBS itself is a great organization.
Company building is also very good.
They understand their social responsibilities and support charities.
cons:
Cons: 

1. Once you join, hikes are very less. People get average 4% hike yearly. So it is very important that one should be aware of  the cost of living in Gurgaon and do not let RBS HR fool you with a lower package, while joining the company. Because that will be the salary you have to survive for the entire time, you will spend in RBS. 

2. All the work is done by Software designers in this gurgaon office and they are not paid any bonuses if not in the favorite list. Promotions are impossible to get.

3. If you are into development, settle for the minimum CTC = (your years of experience * 2.25). This is because whether you work for say 2 or 4 years - yearly appraisals like 2.5%, 4%, 3% will not increase your joining CTC much and you need to survive and maintain your living standards. Also to compensate for all the hard work you will be doing without any promotions and meager hikes.

4. They will ask developers to also do support activities on weekends without any extra pay.

headline: This organization likes to lose money, it's in their DNA as is an underlying level of hypocrisy
pros: Lack of investment in systems, infrastructure and support mean you get a broader scope as you inevitably end up having to all this non-core stuff yourself. Their marketing strap-line is ‘make it happen’ and they live by that. Want something to work or need some support? Then make it happen yourself!
cons: There’s an underlying hypocrisy at play within the firm which is quite frankly extremely infuriating. The depart I worked in, HR, was run by an extremely critical and micro-managing management team. All of their business decisions were born out of on cutting of costs and he was definitely from the ‘talk the talk but do not walk the walk’ school of management. The business was increasingly held back by his policies and decisions. This was compounded by the fact that these policies were not applied to themselves when looking to extend their own ex-pat package. The local compensation team were taken out of the equation and their package was developed as an ‘under the counter’ deal. The management team are extremely aggressive and it is not uncommon for people to be bullied on a daily basis, at least in the Hong Kong office this was my experiences.

headline: Mixeed experience
pros:
1. There are good chances that you might work with some of the greatest coders ( UK contractors ).
2. Get to learn investment banking. RBS had great training programs for employee. But they have been discontinued or downgraded.
3. Good food.
4. Cab  pick and drop anywhere in NCR.
cons:
1. Very low levels of salary and annual growth ( 0.75 % average).
2. Middle management is a bunch of internal employees promoted because they have stayed with RBS for too long. Totally uninspiring lot.
3. Extreme bias while performance appraisals and bonus. Those close to management get paid well regardless of performance.
4. 90% projects are maintenance projects. So not much to learn technically. And unfortunately RBS does nothing to force you learn.
5. Firing are not too often but they happen and it is random. If you are not in good books then you might get fired unless you are really needed.

headline: Work Culture at RBS
pros: It has a very consultative culture within RBS. It practises a fair amount of flexibility within the various BUs which I have personally supported as HR.
cons: Due to the economic climate of UK and Europe markets, and of course an untimely acquisition of ABN in 2008, it led to the global downsizing of the bank. Quite a lot of controls in place, and budgetary constraints and thus limit the expansion of the bank. But RBS Asia is still relatively a reputable bank to work for. There is still a strong client base in Asia. Their pay is rather competitive too.

cons:
Poor Growth Prospects, no long term plan for employees, idea is to recruit resource as per requirement of UK people and keep them in that role as long as possible i.e. like most banks it treats it's employees as contractors.
Company is in huge debt, gloomy and uncertain future.
Occasional firing
UK Control
Poor coordination and understanding between UK and Indian IT Management

headline: Hopeless and pitiful

cons: The most misguided, pitiful and political company I ever worked in and they are in a free fall. A major reorg at least once a year, very mediocre management, all good people are gone, the incompetents stayed behind. Hideous politics as everyone is trying to survive. Terrible reputation.

headline: Inelligent people wasting time.
pros: The only upside of working in RBS I felt was the colleagues has interesting attitude towards work. RBS has an excellent interview programme which has at least 5 technical rounds so they employees coming in some one of the best in their experience group. Good company for married girls.
cons: Many downsides, it could be years before you can change platforms/Technology. Middle management is stupid and could not handle pressure, its more or less being run by techies. No promotion policy from past 6 months. Top management is extremely unstable, new deputy CIO left organization within 6 months. Many other higher management guys are also leaving.

headline: Whatever mistakes the company may have made, they proved an excellent and courteous employer.
pros: Emphasis on teamwork, good communication, higher-ups' doors were always open.
cons: Deadlines and expectations were sometimes unrealistic, but this could normally be surmounted by coordinating with other teams to ensure that the overflow was handled.

headline: Dominated by middle management and a lack of involvement with the general staff.
pros: Modern facilities, in major cities. Account benefits for all staff members such as extended overdraft, travel insurance and pension plans.
cons: With the bank split into business and customer clients bases, the focus is really directed away from customers as the majority of profits comes from business clients. As a result the side of the business that deals with customers tends to be filled with the less ambitious, more incompetent staff. There is a great deal of jumping through hoops required to get to a position of responsibility where you are capable of affecting the status quo.

headline: Great learning experience
pros: I worked in the Private Banking division as a client service manager. Lots of opportunities to learn, great exposure to HNI clients and wealth management in general. Decent work-life balance; if you work hard enough you will become comfortable with the role reasonably quickly. Great people within the division to learn from as well.
cons: The bank cannot compete as effectively as Indian private banks or its foreign counterparts due to a far smaller branch network and a lower risk appetite. Thus, the business was on a downswing as at the time of my departure.

headline: company with no moral values

headline: Not an Equal Opportunity Company
pros: RBS is a good paymaster though its not the same as it used to be. The facilities and HR policies are much better than many other organizations.
cons:
A big fat middle layer with focus on visibility rather than work. RBS typically takes 3-6 months to fill a position that causes overwork for existing positions or saying no to business.

But the biggest issue is very less or no decision making power with Project Managers and BAs sitting in India offices. Even very senior BAs in India typically are not supposed to talk to Business directly. Project Managers in India also have to struggle to put across their point to their UK counterparts. With reorganization every 6 months, Management is always busy in finding a better position rather than focusing on work.

headline: Unfortunate place to work that I would not recommend to anyone.

Do not care of career path and could care less if you leave

headline: Started Great but Ended Disappointingly
pros: When I first started, it was very busy but I learned a ton.  The last year I was there, it had a very relaxed atmosphere.  Throughout my time, the people were very nice, which I think makes it different from other investment banks on the street.
cons: RBS's brand just can't compete with other U.S. investment banks when it comes to M&A or other advisory type businesses. Therefore, it should focus on what it's good at - lending and cash management.  The move to Stamford was a terrible idea.  Towards the end, there was just poor direction from senior management.

headline: Thrown around as ping-pong ball
pros:
Good pay, good benefits, flexibility in terms of work-life balance. 
People tend to be relaxed about their job - a bit too relaxed
cons:
Management doesn't really get it  in terms of what it takes to be a competitive bank.
Very political - people who have been there for the longest have an advantage.
Does not seem to be a meritocracy - it is NOT true that the best ideas are encouraged
Extremely few are genuinely interested in doing what is right for the bank. 
Plans of action are backwards: instead of first establishing the goals and then the way to get there, there is an undue focus on structure, meetings, processes, without a clear understanding of what the point is. 
No willingness to cut deeply and eliminate excess jobs, but rather a slow and painful bleed - affects morale a lot.

headline: Incompetent Senior Management and Leadership Team
pros:
Very good company in terms of,
1. Work-Life balance
2. Very good projects
3. Good learning opportunity
4. Opportunity to work with multiple vendors
5. Very good pay [this will be a problem when you decide to quit, as no other company in the  market agrees to pay this much]
cons:
1. Incompetent leadership team which do not even understand the basics of the project requirements.
2. No governance on the Onsite-Offshore model. Offshore team has no control over the Vendors.
3. Offshore team has no contact with the onsite business team and has no reputation for their hardwork. Vendors will obviously setup an onsite team which works closely works with the business users, and takes all the credits of offshore RBS team.
4. No visibility for the offshore team. Management takes no responsibility or initiative in maintaining good relation with the business users onsite and strengthen inhome capabilities.
5. No transparency on the rationale behind taking decisions, anything can go bad at anytime which will screw up the entire project inspite of good resources and inhome capabilities.
6. There is no one to monitor the vendor resources in the offshore. Vendors do not have any work at all, they slack all the time on personal works and subsequently enjoy free cab ride in addition to a hefty billing towards the project.
7. Notice Period is another tragedy in RBS. You must serve 3 months of Notice during which all your access to the project will be stripped off. There is no flexibility in negotiating the notice period even if the resource has no work at all.
8. No transparency in deciding bonus and hike. Members within the same team can get different amount of bonus and hikes...irrespective of their performance. If you really perform well at work and do not spend time chatting with your manager then you are likely to get no pay hike and zero bonus...beware!!!
9. All sort of unnecessary things are done first [like improving gym, dormitory, worker collaboration, library, internet kiosk], and all important things related to project decisions are taken slowly...making the resource to hate the workplace.
10. Logical thinking among Managers is out of picture. Most of managers here aim only getting a ransom pay, bonus, etc., and no justice is done in terms of work....if you are a Manager then its a very good company to work till retirement, as no one will chuck you out even if you just fill the spaces for namesake.

headline: Best way to spend summer
pros: Very and i mean VERY friendly atmosphere, very relaxed and not pushing for work. People "down to earth" not like in some other IBs.

headline: Was happy to leave
pros: Initially the money was good, as was the reputation. Most of the people I worked with directly were actually quite nice.
cons: But things went downhill very quickly. It was a rudderless ship, and you felt it all the way down the lines. I found that those in the US were treated as secondary citizens in many ways. We rarely got information from management in a timely manner and our benefits were far from comparable to our UK colleagues. Maternity benefits were laughable as were the almost constant employee satisfaction questionnaires. I'm confident no one paid any attention to those.
